39373366.review:
Enjoyed the game alot. The levels are very well-designed, I had fun collecting all the tumors, though some were pretty well-hidden and I couldn't find them all without a guide. Ash is super fun to control, very responsive and fast. The entire soundtrack is made of remixes from classical music and I fucking love it. 

Now a few things that bothered me. Most levels are forgettable and look very bland. Sometimes, it's hard to see what kills you and what doesn't, some tumors are very easy to miss because of all the dark colors.

Cartridge levels. Fuck those. I completed Super Meat Boy 100%(not the achievements) and none of the levels in that game made me rage as much as the cartridge levels. Rings can be very hard to see with bright backgrounds, I unintentionally hit "NO" in the continue screen so many times, they're not fun to look at, I didn't like the retro music, and it's frustatingly difficult.

Thankfully, cartridge levels are just a bonus and only give you extra tumors. Everything else in the game was great. If you enjoyed Super Meat Boy and you like what you see in this game's trailers, give The End Is Nigh a try.

39262027.review:
The End is Nigh est un très bon jeu et on remarque tout de suite qu'Edmund McMillen en est à l'origine.

Le gameplay est parfait et la difficulté est bien présente, à l'instar d'un Super Meat Boy. Si vous trouvez le jeu de base trop facile, pas de soucis, attaquez-vous aux niveaux rétro : certains sont atrocement difficiles et je dois bien avouer que je n'ai pas réussi à tous les terminer (j'en ai laissé beaucoup en chemin ^^). Pourtant j'ai terminé le jeu avec les tumeurs (objets du jeu à collecter) de chaque niveau récupérées.

Le principe du jeu est très simple : vous contrôlez une sorte de petite créature ronde et noir et vous devez avancer, sauter, vous agripper pour éviter les nombreux pièges et avancer d'un niveau à l'autre en récupérant, si vous le voulez, les tumeurs qui y sont. Il y a différents mondes qui se différencient par une DA bien spécifique ainsi que par des mécanismes propres.

Jouer à ce jeu est un réel plaisir même si certaines phases mettent vos nerfs à rude épreuve. La satisfaction de venir à bout d'un lieu difficile sera d'autant plus grande. A noter également une excellente bande-son accompagnant les différents mondes du jeu.

En résumé, The End is Nigh est un de mes coups de cœur de l'année 2017, digne héritier de Super Meat Boy, un des premiers jeux indépendants que j'ai connu et apprécié. Je vous le conseille vivement !

39030750.review:
Edmund McMillen returns to the reflex - based, blood vessel-burstingly difficult sub-genre of platformers, bringing us another game in the vein of super meat boy.

The visuals are an unusual mix of grim and cartoonish. Think Meat Boy, but less bouncy: most areas have a colour palette of "black + grey + (another colour.)" The game isn't particularly nice to look at, to be quite honest, but it seems that this was intentional.
The soundtrack is from Ridiculon, the same person who made the music for Isaac: rebirth and its DLCs. It's decent enough overall; it fits the chaos of the "end of the world" theme well. With that said, some of the tracks, particularly those for the Hollows and Golgotha are just obnoxiously loud in pursuit of being "intense."

The core gameplay mechanics are very different from those in Meat Boy, but they work to create a similar gameplay experience. Ash, the player character, can jump variable heights based on how you press the button, jump to and from ledges for increased distance, but he can't freely wall jump. This single change leads to more inventive and engaging level design. 
Each area also has its own fair share of unique enemies and stage objects, which make gameplay more advanced without alienating the player by changing the core mechanics. Overall, the level design is exceptionally good, giving each area its own unique feel.
The game has plentiful secret levels, most of which can be found through a secret exit to a main level. They aren't hard to find, but they don't need to be; they still feel satisfying to find. The secret levels themselves were designed by Tyler Glailel as opposed to McMillen, so they don't have the same level design genius to them, and a lot of them devolve into "go to the end and get back while being shot at by several enemies." they feel like something you'd find in Mario Maker: difficult but not due to good design.

Despite this, The End is Nigh is a fantastic game, and if you enjoyed Meat Boy or any such games you will probably love it.

38905181.review:
I love everything about this game. If you are a huge fan of tough as nails platformers ala Super Meat Boy, then this game will be right up your alley. It starts off easy enough but it gets much much harder as time progresses. I've even read from the developers themselves that the goal of this game was to crush your spirits and reduce you to hopelessness as the game progresses. I can safely say they have achieved that goal as there are times where I have just found myself looking at the screen thinking "How the hell am I supposed to even begin to do this?"

This is a good thing though. The game may be tough as nails at times and make you want to rip your hair out or throw the controller across the room but the game is always fair. The controls are tight and responsive and any time you end up as splattered poop (as my girlfriend so lovingly refers to the deaths as) it's your fault and your fault alone.

I absolutely love this game. I love it so much so that I actually ended up buying it on Steam after buying it for my Switch. I wanted to try to gather all of the achievements on Steam and compare them with my friends.

Overall, I highly recommend this game and if you are a fan of tough platformers or platformers in general then I think you will find something you like in this game too. Buy it and start dying!

38883983.review:
Un cúmulo de petróleo parlante deja su videojuego favorito y se pone a buscar tumores para construir un amigo en la soledad tras una catástrofe. ¿De qué otra mente iba a salir una idea tan genial como esa? Sí, Edmund está detrás de este juego (Junto a Tyler Glaiel) y esa es razón más que suficiente para que todos comparen The End is Nigh con Super Meat Boy. Si ponemos uno de los dos juegos de cara al otro, son dos experiencias distintas que no se complementan y que sí, tienen algunas innegables similitudes, pero en general son dos títulos bastante diferentes.

Si en su momento te gustó lo que este señor hizo con Meat Boy, acá tenés un plataformero que sorprende lo mismo o incluso más. Artísticamente es bastante bonito dentro de lo que cabe, y la banda sonora es un 10/10 clavadito, pero quiero destacar algo...
No todos son así, pero la inmensa mayoría de los niveles están cuidados al nanómetro para tener ventaja sobre ti. A ratos te darás cuenta de que tus posibles movimientos estaban calculados con anterioridad cual Gran Hermano sabiendo exactamente lo que vas a hacer y decir, pues ese "pinchito" no estaba puesto ahí por casualidad, estaba porque Edd y Tay sabían perfectamente qué planeabas hacer. Otros escenarios darán algún pequeño giro cerca del final para que acabes enterándote que, cuando creías que ya lo habías conseguido, sólamente caíste creyéndote que había tarta al final de la ciencia. Y como dije antes, no todos los niveles son así, pero incluso los que no denotan un diseño particularmente trabajado están pulidos hasta la saciedad.

Además creo estar descubriendo un nuevo fetiche en mí, porque morir y repetir un nivel mil veces se me hace hasta placentero pues el control está, también, muy bien hecho. ¡Pero la cosa no acaba ahí! Actualmente siento una pereza enorme con los logros. Me la sudan, la mayoría implican hacer cosas que terminan culminando en mi aburrimiento... Pero aquí no. A todo lo anteriormente dicho súmale una interfaz y unos menús realmente cómodos para tener control y visión sobre tu progreso en el juego y en los coleccionables... y creo que por fin deseo, IMPLORO conseguir esos logros.

En fin, uno de los mejores plataformeros que toqué en mi vida, así de simple.

38765130.review:
Note: this is a very tentative thumbs down, and it is definitely not a bad game, I just didn't like it. Maybe you will.

I really want to like this game. I loved SMB. I will probably buy The Binding of Isaac at some point. But this game just wasn't really fun. The art style is a lot like SMBs, but darker and more drab. The black silhouette blocks got old pretty quickly. The moving blocks and water and other stuff are nice additions, and would have been welcome in Super Meat Boy, and the level design is just as good. The soundtrack is well made, though it clashes with the art. And the classical tunes don't compare to anything by D.B. The ledge grab mechanics work, and so do the continuous levels instead of a level select screen, but they seem there mostly to make it different from SMB.

Overall, a pretty good game, but if you have seen Super Meat Boy this seems almost unfinished and half-baked by comparison and if you haven't Super Meat Boy is the better game. Super Meat Boy also seems to have more content, and is very fun to play and less drab and a better soundtrack. Maybe buy this at a discount.

38651619.review:
Le dernier chef-d’œuvre d'Edmund McMillen, tout simplement.
On retrouve la recette qui a fait le succès de ses précédents titres : un gameplay simple mais qu'il faudra maitriser à la perfection si vous voulez venir à bout du jeu.

Si vous avez aimé Super Meat Boy jetez-vous sur The End is Nigh, c'est une suite tout à fait honorable. De la plateforme hardcore, une difficulté bien dosée, des [strike]bandages[/strike] tumeurs à ramasser, des passages secrets et des niveaux rétro.
Un petit air de déjà vu donc, mais ça tombe bien, on en redemandait !

On regrettera tout de même la présence de plateformes demandant une certaine rapidité avant de disparaitre définitivement de l'écran, un peu trop nombreuses à mon goût, elles apportent une certaine frustration, obligeant trop souvent à recommencer le même tableau en boucle, là où Super Meat Boy privilégiait le timing et la précision.

Petite mention pour les musiques, le duo Ridiculon nous livre ici des reprises de grands titres de la musique classique qui, si elles n'arriveront pas à faire oublier les compositions de Danny Baranowsky, méritent largement qu'on y jette une oreille.

38185368.review:
I am giving this one a thumbs up since it is well done and succeeds at doing what it attempts to, but would probably not recommend it to most people.

I normally enjoy challenging games (loved Super Meat Boy, Cuphead, Dark Souls, etc); dying, learning what you did wrong, and then improving & eventually overcoming an obstacle really gives a sense of accomplishment.  The first 55-60% or so (judging from my completion %) gave me this feeling, but ultimately turned into more of a test of patience than I am willing to put up with. The game really isn’t about learning patterns and overcoming obstacles, but rather precision jump after precision jump and just grinding through it until you finally get that perfect run.  There are plenty of levels and bonus content, but there honestly isn’t much variety and all comes down to landing jumps with no margin of error, often in quick succession.

I consider myself to be above average at this type of game, but am starting to lose interest as the final 40% seems more like a grind rather than a fun challenge to overcome.  If you enjoy grinding through levels and/or have top tier mechanics at games like this, then absolutely play this one.  There is a ton of content and plenty of secrets/different paths to discover.  If you’re in the same boat as me then expect a fun game similar to Super Meat Boy for about five hours before it becomes too much.  Otherwise I would skip this one!

游戏时长20小时终于完成主线关卡，重新回到开始的地方真的倍感亲切。

卡带关还要继续努力，不知道还要打多久。

横向对比SMB的话游戏难度较低，毕竟这游戏讲究的是一个收集，而SMB是速度。
操作感来说还不错，技巧和时机都要把控，技巧更重要一些。
关卡设置来说很棒，循序渐进的难度增强，未来世界的巧妙加强，都让人在提高的过程中并不乏味。隐藏设置的也是一大亮点，不过重复打图还是挺烦躁的一件事情。
剧情方面没怎么看，而且英语水平比较渣，就不强行分析了。

总之这是一个很优秀的游戏，E胖没有让我感到失望。
推荐SMB玩家入手，难度方面虽然横向对比会简单些但难度并不低，没玩过类似游戏的建议观望下，以免吃灰或者砸键盘。

At an hour in, I can say I would recommend TEIN to other lovers of hardcore platformers. Steam has too few of these types of games. 

As a veteren of Super Meat Boy from back in the Xbox arcade days, this is right up my alley. The controls are tight, but a little sloppier than SMB. Ive tried steam controller (sucks) and Xbox 1 (better), but cant imagine playing on keyboard. Just seems like the horizontal speed and jump height are too touchy, unpredicably so.
But I suppose thats a part of the challenge, I just remember SMB being tighter. Maybe Im getting too old.

Anyway, TEIN is a great game, although definately for adults only. Right from the intro video its fbombs, and the "characters" you meet along the way often alude to masturbation as being the reason they are where they are. Just thought I would throw that out there for other parents. Steam doesnt do a good job of rating content, not that it would have stopped me from buying. Just would have waited for the kids to be in bed before playing.

Do make sure you have a monitor with a good black contrast, the whole game is basically shades of black or grey, at least the first two worlds Ive made it to.

But yeah, if youre into hardcore difficulty (why else would you be on this store page?) this is a must buy, I agree with the underrated status. Once it hits Xbox and PS4 I think we will see tshirts and backpacks just like SMB.

9.5/10 - would get high blood pressure again

37909372.review:
Okay, so I'm really *bad* at this game. About 3 hours in, sitting at almost 900 deaths kinda bad. I routinely play for five or ten minutes, swear a bunch, and then quit.

But I keep coming back for more, so I must be getting some enjoyment out of the process? I'm still honestly not sure.

If you like VVVVVV and/or Super Meat Boy, you'll probably like this, gameplay-wise. The controls are solid. The challenge level is somewhere between "hurts so good" and "wow, you really hate yourself, don't you?" If you have godly reaction times and incredibly precise jumping skills, probably it will hurt a lot less. Us mere mortals will suffer.

If you like the aesthetic of Edmund McMillen's other games, you'll undoubtedly like this one. I find the music a little grating in places, but that's probably because I spend so much time in the same areas trying to make progress. The visuals are suitably apocalypse-gloomy but still enjoyable to look at. 

The amount of collectables is big, but not overwhelming. Many are obvious, but some take extra exploration and a staggering amount of skill to get at. You get catridges within the game to basically play more of the game, but in an even cuter retro/pixel style.

Short version: do it if you like hard platformers. If the space between "I know how to get across the screen" and being able to actually get there makes you crazy, DO NOT.

37767062.review:
Après Super Meat Boy et Binding of Isaac, Edmund McMillen & Cie continue de nous faire souffrir avec ce The End is Nigh.

Vous incarnez Ash, vraisemblablement le dernier survivant du monde, désireux de se fabriquer un ami afin de ne plus être seul. Vous devrez ainsi parcourir un monde post-apocalyptique à la recherche des éléments nécessaires à la création du parfait ami. Encore une fois, l'humour est très noir et l'univers est bien torturé, mais très cohérent avec le level design.

On pourrait résumer le gameplay à une seule action : sauter. En vrai, il y a plusieurs subtilités. On peut déjà doser son saut, notion qui sera essentielle pour progresser. On pourra ensuite s'accrocher sur les rebords des plateformes ainsi que sur certains "crochets", ce qui permettra de prendre appui pour un saut plus haut ou bien de s'élancer tel Nathan Drake à l'opposé du rebord. Il y a enfin une sorte d'attaque rodéo utilisée pour casser certains sols et pour plonger plus vite. Ah, et il y a aussi des passages sous l'eau. Tout est très simple, mais diablement précis et efficace. Entendez par là que si vous mourez, ce sera de votre faute :p.

Si le début du jeu est relativement facile, ça se corse assez vite, mais progressivement. Il y a une bonne dizaines de mondes différents, chacun apportant de nouveaux éléments de level design (eau, nuages toxiques, tapis roulants, etc...). Puis il y a les tous derniers niveaux du jeu, assez durs mais pas insurmontables. Et puis il y a le contenu bonus, qui vous fera vous arracher les yeux si vous osez vous y attaquer. Il s'agit de niveaux reprenant les mondes de bases, mais avec un aspect retro 8-bits du plus bel effet. Mais ne vous y trompez pas, ces niveaux sont d'une difficulté très relevée. Par contre, la satisfaction de les réussir est incomparable.

Bref, The End is Nigh est encore une grande réussite de McMillen, qui saura vous occuper entre 5h et 6h (et des heures assez intenses), et plus si vous tentez d'atteindre le 100%. En plus d'avoir un univers atypique, le gameplay et le level design sont en parfaite cohésion et d'une rigueur remarquable.

I feel like this game is somewhat underrated. I guess Edmund thought it will automaticly be as popular as Super Meat Boy because it is so similar but I think it lacked marketing.  

Now to talk about the game already: It's great, it's very similar to SMB, and it is just as hard. So your typical hardcore-plattformer.

Despite its unwelcoming appearance, The End is Nigh is a fun, even joyful trial of patience. 36919162.review:
The End Is Nigh is a wonderful game. Its soundtrack is beautiful, all astounding remixes of popular classical music, themed for Edmund's style. The gameplay is incredibly fluid and precise, but not in a way that seems unfair. Everytime I die, I know it was my fault. Beating the game is not too difficult, but if you're going to attempt to 152% the game, good luck. The optional objectives are much more difficult. The story is depressing, but that's true to Edmund's style.

All in all, The End Is Nigh is a treat. A wonderful experience of difficulty, joy, depression, and thrills.

The End Is Nigh is my favorite game of all time.

10/10.

36875450.review:
For anyone who can compare digital scars from seven long years of Super Meat Boy, this game will serve as fresh blood through tired skin. Don't be fooled by the lulling initial stages of instruction and training, you will soon be inches from your monitor screaming or weeping inconsolably after you manage to land perfectly on a tiny outcrop of spikes... again.

As expected from the developer, characters and setting are morbidly cutesy and the controls are ultra-taught and responsive. The true advancement of this game however, is just how well it manipulates you into a strange 'productive' state of anger. In a much more devious way than SMB, The End is Nigh spends time through the first few screens of a chapter training you in the necessary skills (and combinations of skills) needed to progress. It then finds ways of betraying that training in incrementally more irritating ways to slowly devastate you psychologically.

TL;DR - Psychologically devastating, highly recommended.

36497283.review:
Un très gros GG à Edmund et à Glaiel pour ce merveilleux jeu typique du "Die and Retry", attendez vous à passer plusieurs journées dessus (Pas comme moi qui l'a torché en 47 heures (Approximativement, AFK)) Pour le 100% vous allez passer de nombreuses heures sur la même cartouche de jeu afin de la compléter au maximum, si vous n'êtes pas à l'aise avec les jeux compliqués je ne vous le conseille vraiment pas car cela pourrait être un gâchi d'argent, mais je ne pense pas avoir besoin de prévenir, ce jeu à eu une très grosse hype avant sa sortie, donc je pense qu'ici tout le monde doit le connaître.

Malgré ça, j'ai repéré certains défauts (d'après moi à corriger si possible) :
-Le principe du die and retry est bien représenté, mais on peut passer une demi journée sur une cartouche (ce qui peut être perturbant et rageant)
-Il manque un système d'entraîment (Notamment sur la Super Mega Cart) car c'est en apprenant certains niveau qu'on y arrive mieux
-Le système de mapping est plutôt mal géré. En effet, on ne peut pas retourner à un niveau spécifique (Super meat boy) et l'on doit se refaire le monde en entier pour pouvoir aller là où l'on veut aller.
-Les ennemis qui se dupliquent quand on s'approche d'eux sont bien fait, mais sur certains écran, il faut un ordinateur puissant, sinon c'est complètement injouable (Personnellement j'ai été obligé d'utiliser le Speed rate de cheat engine pour passer quelques écrans. Même si la première fois je ne connaissais pas cette technique j'ai mis des dizaines voir vingtaines de minutes à passer un écran tout bidon, sauf que ces ennemis là utilisent énormément de RAM et j'espère qu'il y aura une mise à jour corrigeant un peu la mémoire utilisé par ces ennemis là).

J'énonce en même temps les points fort du jeu tant qu'à faire : 
-Durée de jeu en moyenne entre 50 et 100 heures de jeu facilement (surtout pour le 100%)
-Gameplay simple et original (avec un peut de gameplay de super meat boy)
-Un très bonne histoire de Ash parcourant le monde pour se faire un ami et de récupérer des cartouches de jeu
-Une difficulté plutôt bien dosée (Pas trop simple, ni trop dur)
-De NOMBREUX secrets plus ou moins bien cachés
-Un monde en 8-bit grâce aux cartouches de jeu collecté sur votre chemin
-De très bon graphismes également avec un personnage très bien réalisé

Pour ma part ce jeu est un franc succès, c'est pour cela que je vous le conseille, il en vaut vraiment la peine !

36392145.review:
It's easily the best 2D platformer I've played in a long time.
Controls are tight, and platforming itself is changed dramatically in a way I personally liked from something like Super Meatboy by removing wall-jumping and adding the ability to hang off of ledges.
I felt oddly incentivised to collect all of the collectibles (barring ones received from the ridiculuous end-game challenges) which are put in each level in a place that requires some extra platforming to reach, and this is always a good thing.

The soundtrack is the co-star of the show as far as I'm concerned, with every piece being a remixed version of a classical song, like 'Flight of the Bumblebee' and 'In the Hall of the Mountain King'. The music fits the game so damned well and elevates it from a great platformer to a genuinely exciting and bombastic experience.

Get it if you like 2D platformers, classical music, Edmund McMillan, or challenging yourself with difficult gameplay.

36387430.review:
Basically this is off-brand Super Meat Boy, except from the original creator. I didn't feel like it was as much fun as SMB, and most of the obvious design changes feel like downgrades. But it still is a solid game and worth playing if you're a genre fan.

Good points: Creative mechanics in some levels. High number of secret areas (though they don't feel particularly rewarding except the Future sections). One of the later levels (The Machine) makes very good use of the different level structure compared to SMB. Decent aesthetics. Tight controls and good level design.

Gripes compared to SMB: You can't warp to any room, just the start of an area. The soundtrack is just a bunch of public domain remixes instead of SMB's great original tracks. The deliberate limited color pallette makes it VERY hard to see things that can kill you, or the borders between what counts as floor and what counts as wall (both VERY bad things in this genre, especially since it's still true in the sections with limited lives). Any part with acid water comes down to frustrating button mashing. There's no alternate characters at all, so the only unlockables are more levels. No per-level speedrun timer or par time.

36384816.review:
I had always wished for Super meat boy 2. And while my first impression was that The End is nigh would offer a similiar experience, there's some aspects of the game that I'm not quite as fond of.

My biggest critique are the interconnected levels. I have no idea who thought that this would be a good idea in a game like this. It's not "hard", it's unnecessarily tedious, unfortunately. If you are a completionist, the game makes you replay the same (insanely hard and frustrating) levels over and over, and some tumours can only be accessed from one side of the map, meaning you have to start over at world-1 if you want to collect them all. This circumstance 
leads me to not wanting to 100% the game like I did with SMB, as it, unfortunately, feels more like a chore at times. I honestly believe being able to warp to certain areas would definitely make the game a lot more fun to complete. 

Second is the lack of pure, unadultered platforming in some of the levels. Sure, there are the cartridge levels (which are great), but some levels involve hoping the AI of some stupid enemy is behaving the way you need it to. 

All in all, The end is Nigh is another great platformer by Team meat, but isn't quite able to live up to its predecessor. If you're a fan of SMB and other hard platformers, you should go ahead and play this anyway. Despite its flaws, it's still without a doubt one of the best platformers of recent times. The controls are tight and most of the level design is amazing.

36329936.review:
People often like to compare this game to Super Meat Boy, and while it is a fair thing to do seeing as Edmund Mcmillen is responsible for the creation of them both I can assure you that The End is Nigh is it's own unique experience with lots of exploration, collecting and tough platforming to do. The controls are a lot tighter than it's cousin Super Meat Boy, in fact they're so good it makes SMB feel floaty and slippery after going back. The main quest is easy enough for the average platforming fan to complete but the bonus content is hard yet gripping enough to keep you playing after the 20th failure or so while still remaining fun. The soundtrack is amazing and is one of the very few times I have ever purchased a video game soundtrack and I am still listening to it even now even as I type this review.

TEiN does have one major flaw,  the colour scheme. while I am a huge fan of it in some areas it is quite difficult to distinguish hazards from safe terrain such as in The Future and some areas with visual effects such as The Hollows. Other than that however my experience with the game was a great one and would definitely recommend this to fans of the platforming genre or just hardcore Edmund Mcmillen fans. (such as myself) The End is Nigh is a very nice and sweet hidden gem of 2017 and I can definitely see myself coming back to it for another round sooner or later.

36329244.review:
It took me a little while to warm up to this game after spending a long time speedrunning Super Meat Boy. The soundtrack felt hit-or-miss, the platforming felt a little bit slower, and the lack of diversity in the gameplay felt a bit dull in comparison to the vast number of playable characters and bosses in SMB. 

As I kept playing through, it all began to click. The End Is Nigh is a different experience than Super Meat Boy, yet equally rewarding as a tough-as-nails platformer. The movement in this game is slower yet still exceptionally tight, resulting in a platforming experience that requires more thoughtful decision-making than SMB, with about the same amount of precision. In effect, dying never feels particularly unfair in this game. Whereas I would sometimes call into question a death in Super Meat Boy, I feel like the mistakes that I make in The End Is Nigh are 100% on me. Even with the slower platforming, that adrenaline rush that comes with clearing a group of stages in a row is as intact as ever, which makes subsequent replays of TEIN a delight rather than a chore. 

The story that the game tells is grittier, more mature, and funnier. Ash's bizarre optimism in the face of desperation is charming and poignant. The level environments support the storytelling by feeling like a more connected universe than Super Meat Boy, in part because of the immediate flow from one chapter into the next. You feel like you're taking Ash on a little adventure in this game. 

As a byproduct of this connected, adventurers-welcome world, TEIN offers really no semblance of downtime, which makes speedrunning the game a nightmarish thrill ride. I've spent a couple hundred hours beating this game over and over and I still feel like I'm just getting started. I can't recommend TEIN enough for people who love to push their platforming skills to the outer limits -- you will find that this game will reward you in spades if you stick with it through the bitter end.

36069062.review:
(Please note, this review was written based off the 2 first hours of gameplay. I bought the game on sale for $10)

Edmund Mcmillen is easily one of my favorite game developers. Sure, he's had his slip-ups recently (I'm looking at you, Rebirth DLC) but he still makes some honestly good games. The main issue I believe the Rebith DLC had was just...how  unenthusiased he seemed for Binding of Isaac. I believe that had a huge detriment on the quality of those two DLCs.
But lord behold, we have a new IP from him! Unless this is a Time Fcuk sequel. I'm honestly not quite sure.

[h1] THE END IS NIGH! [/h1]

The game I've been waiting for so so long. Or at least, was. The teasers on the Isaac devblog gave me absolute Meatboy blueball. I needed this game. It looked incredible. And only now am I buying it, a [i]BIT[/i] late to it's release. And let me tell you, these first two hours have been an experience.

The intro to the game caught me pleasantly off guard, a... lovely introduction to the odd world. Essentially, the premise of the game is that...well, it's The End. The world is in shambles. Oh, but who cares about that! You're on a quest to build a friend out of tumours, and to play video games! Both IRl and in-game.

While the pallette could use a bit of work in some areas, I love the atmosphere of the game's world. It captures the gloomy, yet sort of non-serious mood. Edmund's classic artstyle is greatly shown off and modernized. It's simply beautiful to look at, with how smooth all the lines and little details are.

I believe it is important to note that [u]this is not as much of a Meatboy clone as you might think it is.[/u] You can really tell Edmund put some elbow grease into making sure it wasn't too similar.
If you were a fan of the wall jumping, I have some bad news. It's dead. Kinda. So let's hope you like edge grabbing, similar to Spelunky's. One might think right off the bat that this removes the freedom of the game, and in some regards, yes, it does. It only allows you to walljump in certain areas, right? Whilst in Meatboy, if you wanted to scale a wall, the chips were yours. Well, with the way the levels are designed, I believe it fits this game perfectly. It makes secrets far more intricate to get to, and it really makes you think outside the box sometimes, with how you handle certain situations.
And, don't worry. There's plenty of platforming variations. Water, and springs are a couple of examples. Don't get TOO mad.~

Let's talk secrets for a second. Yeah, it's Edmund, what'dya expect? Of course it's gonna have tons of secrets. But, be warned. Getting to some of them can be a tad bit annoying. Sometimes requring you to do a series of overly-specific jumps and such, sometimes in a timed manner, to get to.
In terms of collectibles, say goodbye to Bandages, and say hello to Tumours. For almost every stage, there is a tumour to collect. Collect enough tumours, and you get access to challenge stages, which usually hold a catridge at the end, as well. The cartridges perform similarly to Meatboys; a series of levels that you must get through, only with a specific number of lives, or sometimes only one life! It sort of disappointed me to see multiple character unlocks not included, but I think this is a pretty okay solution to including in these challenge and retro levels. Rather than having to hunt down some absurdly hidden warpzone.

Now, some may disagree with me, but in my opinion, the most unique part about the game are the stages. And I'm not talking design; I'm talking how they're pieced together. For you see, there is no world map here, with levels to choose from. You go along the game by walking from one stage to the next. This opens up SO many possibilities for secrets to be placed, as well as alternate ways to handle platforming. And it really just fits the game's pace perfectly. Once again, Edmund trying to differentiate the game from Meatboy. I like it.

And if you're a sucker for kicking soundtracks, this is just the game. Each soundtrack fits almost perfectly with each scenario. I honestly don't see why Ridiculon gets so much shade thrown at them. They've made great music for both Isaac, and now this [url=https://ridiculon.bandcamp.com/track/ruin-in-the-hall-of-the-mountain-king-grieg-1875]work of art.[/url]

[h1]All things aside, this game is honestly worth your time and money if you're a sucker for platformers, especially if you're a Meatboy fan. The graphics and aesthetics are gorgeous, it sports some brilliant platforming elements, and it has plenty of things to collect and do. Edmund wanted to avoid making Meatboy 2: Gush Edition™, and he succeeded brilliantly. Haha, be warned though, it's kind of, uh. Hard.[/h1]

[code] If you have any feedback for my review, I would greatly appreciate it. Have a nice day.[/code]

35861443.review:
This is the only game I have ever refunded, if that tells you anything. 

I'm usually a big fan of Edmund - I played SMB and both Binding of Isaac games a ton and thoroughly enjoyed them. I never minded the difficulty and actually enjoyed the sense of achievement that comes with it.

The difficulty here, though, is simply not enjoyable at all. For example, it wasn't until now that I fully appreciated the genius of how SMB would play back your cumulative deaths each time you died. That way, even in the midst of frustration, you could always either laugh at seeing that 90% of your deaths were a single jump at the beginning OR you could look at that other 10% and get a sense of progress. In this game, you will die, immediately respawn in an oddly jarring way and die again 2 seconds later. 

Finally, I should note that, for the most part, my complaints are most relevant for the far more difficult extra levels. If you can be satisfied running through the standard levels without exploration or tackling the major challenges, you may be fine. However, if you're like me, you'll probably feel compelled to play through ALL the content and, if so, prepare for major disappointment and frustration. 

In summary, Edmund once again delivers on the promise of a difficult platformers. The problem is, this time around, he forget to include any real sense of achievement or progress that made his other games bearable.

35825674.review:
"The End is Nigh" is "Super Meat Boy"'s harder and slower cousin and spiritual successor. You play as Ash, a "human-like blob thing" who has managed to survive the end of the world. Set out on a quest to make a friend and collect video game cartridges. It's HARD.

Once again another good game from Mcmillen & Co, this time another platformer. One of the main gimmicks this time around is that instead of having a wall jump like you did in meat boy, you now instead grab onto any and all ledges and can then either jump upwards off of them or fling yourself off the wall to gain some horizontal velocity. I say gimmick because it doesn't always feel quite right and more often than not it felt like i wasn't grabbing onto ledges when i should have been. Not a huge problem, but quite a bit frustrating.

The game is pretty hard but there isn't a huge penalty for dying (except in the last 75% of the game) so no problemo. If you are decent at platformers i'd say there is around 8 hours of gameplay. (unless you're going for all the achievements and endings, then times that by like 4) Just be warned that if you end up getting the regular ending that there is a timed section that is a pain in the ass to complete. (but it's the final level so it's a good kind of pain in the ass)

The soundtrack is just remixed classical melodies and it sounds freaking badass. My favourite tracks are RUIN and ACCEPTANCE. Great work on the OST Ridiculon.

Overall i would give it a 7.5 out of 10. I'm not sure if i like it more than Super Meat Boy as the speed that i loved in that game isn't really present here until the final stage and even then it's still pretty slow. I do recommend it though, especially if you loved previous McMillen games.

Go on, and grab some tumors along the way.

35792726.review:
There's a fine line between hard and fun, and nearly impossible and frustrating. I'm not talking about the main game (excluding the collectibles such as tumours, mega tumours and carts). I'm talking about the massive amount of time needed to get the mega tumours in keyed areas. They are definitely not worth the time. In the time I spent getting a mega tumour (worth 5 tumours) I could've beat the game five times over.

Tumours aside, the game is very fun, beating (most) levels gives a massive sense of acheivement. 


On another note, the arcade games are even more punishing than anything else. Ed, why? just why?




To conclude, this game is very fun if you're feeling patient and don't rage quit every half an hour like I do (just make sure there aren't any valuable or fragile items around you because after an hour of The End is Nigh, they will all be broken) but it is also EXTREMELY punishing. Though it's fun, this game isn't for everyone. 7/10















Also this game is another sign that Edmund McMillen is a fucking sadist. Fuck you Ed
(But thanks for making good games Ed)

35506456.review:
Super Meat Boy demeure l'un des meilleurs jeux de plateformes de tous les temps, un véritable phénomène dont la sortie aura aidé à propulser sur le devant de la scène les jeux indépendants, le [i]old school[/i] et les [i]hardcore platformers,[/i] bouleversant durablement et en profondeur le paysage vidéoludique. Quand l'un des deux coauteurs de ce chef-d'œuvre historique sort un nouveau jeu de plateformes, c'est donc un événement à observer de près.

The End Is Nigh met en scène Ash, dernier survivant d'une apocalypse nucléaire ayant ravagé le globe. Difforme, à moitié décomposé et peut-être déjà mort, Ash passe ce qu'il reste de son temps à jouer à son unique jeu vidéo, The End Is Nigh, qu'il diffuse en streaming sur Internet sans qu'il n'y ait plus personne pour le voir ou l'entendre. Mais un jour, sa cartouche grille sans récupération possible, et Ash, excédé, décide alors de sortir de son abri de fortune pour explorer un monde totalement délabré dans l'espoir d'y dénicher de nouveaux jeux vidéo - et peut-être trouver suffisamment de bouts de bidoche épars à partir desquels il pourra se fabriquer un ami.

Le jeu a de nombreux points communs avec Super Meat Boy: on reconnaît la patte graphique de Edmund McMillen (ici plus épurée et élégante), son humour noir, les références rétro, l'idée d'offrir des variantes plus dures de niveaux déjà visités, et le fameux principe ludique des mini-niveaux très durs mais très courts que l'on peut recommencer sans interruption encore et encore sans avoir à s'enquiquiner avec un message de "Game Over" ou un compteur de vies.

La maniabilité et la structure ludique de The End Is Nigh le distinguent pourtant nettement de Super Meat Boy, du moins au début: le saut mural et le bouton d'accélération ont disparu et il y a donc moins d'inertie dans le [i]platforming,[/i] mais Ash peut en revanche s'agripper à des crochets ou aux angles des blocs à la façon de Prince of Persia et s'en servir comme prise pour se propulser. Il peut aussi effectuer une charge au sol pour descendre plus vite ou briser certains blocs, et ramper pour glisser plus facilement sur les angles des blocs.
Point de vue structure, au lieu du menu de Super Meat Boy qui donnait accès à ses mini-niveaux et permettait de comparer ses meilleurs temps dans un classement en ligne, on a ici une quinzaine de "mondes" comportant chacun entre quinze et vingt écrans faisant office de mini-niveaux, sans scrolling mais connectés bout à bout, avec une circulation libre à la façon d'un jeu de plateformes classique et une grosse emphase sur la collecte: il y a à peu près une "tumeur" par écran (la ramasser est [b][i]beaucoup[/i][/b] plus difficile que simplement atteindre l'écran suivant), ainsi que des "méga tumeurs" et des cartouches de jeu vidéo à dénicher dans des écrans cachés.

Ces éléments font de The End Is Nigh un jeu initialement beaucoup plus posé, plus calme et plus méthodique que Super Meat Boy, plus contemplatif aussi, chose renforcée par sa bande-son composée de musiques classiques remixées. Malgré une difficulté équivalente, l'absence de bouton d'accélération crispe moins les mains et l'absence de chronomètre crispe moins les nerfs, et le [i]level design[/i] tire bien parti des différences de mobilité entre Ash et Meat Boy. Par moments, on se croirait presque dans un [i]puzzle platformer[/i].

Cependant, la difficulté grimpant exponentiellement finit par tout aplanir: plus le jeu devient dur, plus il ressemble à Super Meat Boy, avec des dizaines d'essais successifs enchaînés de façon hypnotique où l'on fonce dès sa régénération pour tenter de se synchroniser avec un [i]level design[/i] hyper nerveux et ultra agressif, et cette proximité ne tourne pas à l'avantage de The End Is Nigh: comme Ash est moins mobile que Meat Boy, le [i]level design[/i] devient plus linéaire et plus pointilleux au fur et à mesure qu'il devient plus dur, jusqu'à atteindre le niveau d'un [i]kaizo platformer[/i]. On ne retrouve pas ici l'équilibre que Super Meat Boy avait réussi à instaurer entre son exigence et son extrême maniabilité, équilibre qui lui permettait de toujours rester fair-play et stimulant même dans ses niveaux les plus sadiques. Le plaisir de jeu de The End Is Nigh s'en ressent amèrement.

En plus de la quinzaine de "mondes" du jeu, on peut jouer à la vingtaine de cartouches que l'on aura dénichées ici ou là. Ces jeux rétro se ressemblent tous et ne sont qu'une version pixelisée du jeu principal, avec des règles qui varient: vies limitées ou infinies, gameplay orienté vers la survie ou la collecte, etc. Certains d'entre eux sont assez longs et ils offrent les défis les plus corsés du jeu et la plupart de ses [i]achievements[/i].

Au final, au moment d'écrire cette critique, j'ai joué à The End Is Nigh une vingtaine d'heures, j'ai bouclé à 100% toute la grosse première partie du jeu (ses neuf premiers "mondes"), j'ai joué à quelques cartouches, et j'ai battu le début des "remix" infernaux de la seconde partie du jeu. Je me suis arrêté non pas parce que le jeu devenait trop dur, mais parce que cette difficulté n'était pour moi plus amusante.

J'ai dans l'ensemble cependant passé un excellent moment sur The End Is Nigh, et je le recommande aux amateurs de [i]hardcore platformers[/i] qui savent où ils mettent les pieds, même si dans le genre "méthodique" je lui ai nettement préféré [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/260790/1001_Spikes/]Aban Hawkins & the 1001 Spikes[/url] par exemple.

35427891.review:
I highly enjoyed this game! The music and visuals and the dialogue give it a really great atmosphere and tone. I found the difficulty very engaging, the main parts of the game I found very satisfying and fun, you die tons, but you respawn so fast it doesn't feel very punishing, making it through the levels was gratifying. The retro levels have limited lives thus are much harder, but they were still fun to complete, though the later ones can get pretty frustrating. I would definitely not recommend this if you're inexperienced in the platforming genre.

The controls are simple but it feels like there's a good amount of mastery and improvement, now that I've finished the game I look forward to watching speedruns of it. There are also many collectibles to gather, some found in hidden areas (the map tells you how many hidden areas are in a world) I found these very satisfying to collect. (There's a good reason to collect them too, if you play the game I recommend getting a lot). 

Overall I really liked adventuring with Ash, it is well worth the full price for the amount of content and challenge found, this is probably one of the best platformers I've played in a long time. Right from the start, it hooked me in with the charm and satisfying gameplay and collectibles. 

It is a very difficult game, but in the non-optional main levels, it never feels too punishing. 

I can't really praise it enough, I had a really great time with it.

35145047.review:
The End is Nigh. It's an insanely difficult platformer just like Super Meat Boy, but it has one key difference: You can't wall jump! This defines the game, and is more fun than it sounds. Because the game centers around hanging on ledges and boost-jumping off of them.

Just like Super Meat Boy, precise controls aid you in your efforts to overcome ridiculous platforming challenges. However, it never overwhelms you with this absurd challenge at first. The game, for the most part, starts at a "moderate" difficulty then very slowly ramps up. Introducing you to harder and harder challenges that are perfectly doable. Even the most absurd platforming problems require subtle button presses and nuanced use of movement, in order to beat them.

The End is Nigh has more value than it seems. Not only does it have a ton of collectible and "adorable" tumors, which are more important than you think, the game has tons of other secrets to find. You'll spend quite a few hours searching for them, and you'll eventually get good enough to traverse the levels to find them all. The game really DOES have over 600 levels in total!

This game doesn't progress like a normal platforming game, such as Super Meat Boy, where you have to SELECT your individual levels. Each world can be selected from a map, but the individual levels within these worlds behave like one big long path. With forks in the road leading to goodies and secrets. You traverse between these worlds via teleporters. In fact, the entire game is one giant path that... almost looks like a pitchfork, due to 3 branching ways you can go.

Visually, the game looks quite good! The signature artstyle is here, with beautiful effects that look rather impressive despite the relatively primitive artstyle. In a way, this game is charming with its morbid atmosphere and sense of humor. There's something almost whimsical about the dark and bleak world of The End is Nigh. Technically, there doesn't seem to be anything wrong, and you have all the options you could want at your disposal, including solid video options.

What makes The End is Nigh so brilliant is that sheer satisfaction you get from beating tough segments. Just like in Edmund McMillen's amazing Super Meat Boy, beating the toughest challenges and secrets will give you a serious amount of "gamer cred". Whatever such a thing is even worth.

The only thing truly hampering this game is the difficulty. If you hate "rage platformers', please for the love of black blobs everywhere, just stay way. But if you're a masochist who gets sick pleasure out of being satisfied from beating tough platformers, this game is highly reccomended!

35124562.review:
To appease the nit-pickers who'll complain about a review any more complex than a list of pros and cons, I'll keep this review short and simple.

[h1]PROS[/h1]
[b]-The game is definitely hard.[/b] 
[i]((LOOK HERE BEFORE SAYING I DON'T LIKE THE GAME FOR BEING TOO HARD))[/i]
-Rich Evans is a good voice actor.
-Jumping on enemies/projectiles is fun.

[h1]CONS[/h1]
-The game has EXTREMELY basic physics; far less fun than what anyone would expect from a game made in 2017, let alone a game made by the same guy who made Super Meat Boy. Nothing makes it stand out aside from the fact that you can jump off of ledges, which isn't exactly anything worth writing home about.
-The second half of the game has lives, and resets your progress once you run out. Lives in a game like this aren't fun, they're just a lazy, tedious way to pad out the game's length. It doesn't make the game any harder, it just makes it more annoying.
-Said lives are based on the amount of tumors you've collected through the first half of the game, which is something you're never told, meaning that if you want more lives, you'll have to go back and play through any incomplete worlds all over again to collect them thanks to the lack of a level select system. Again, this doesn't add any difficulty, and merely pads out the game's length by forcing you to replay levels to reach the ones you missed.

[i]Misc. Complaints[/i]
-The game is ugly. Yes, I get it, the point is that the world is ugly because it's dead, but that doesn't really excuse the fact that every texture is just one solid color. It's boring to look at. Even Super Meat Boy's basic tile-based graphics were much, much better.
-No proper bosses. I'm aware that it's more of a personal thing, and that some people don't like bosses in platformer games, but still, a variety in gameplay would be nice.
-The soundtrack is just bland, generic remixes of public domain songs, with the rare inclusion of a unique song that still doesn't really manage to stand out from the drudge of generic remixes of In The Hall of the Mountain King and Flight of the Bumblebees.
-No level editor. Not that it needed a level editor, I guess, but it's hard to not compare this game to Super Meat Boy and be disappointed by how much it's lacking.

I can say without an ounce of hyperbole that this game feels like some quick flash game made for Newgrounds in the early 2000's. It just makes me wish I was playing Super Meat Boy; multiple characters, better level design, a level editor/in-game custom level prowser, actually fun gameplay, and so on.

34922508.review:
Ash is on a journey to assemble a friend, and he has to jump, dodge, smash and hang out to find the pieces. The End is Nigh is a great game with smooth, simple controls. The platforming varies from easy to extremely difficult, and the cartridges offer a great challenge for people who have completed the main story. Colleting the tumors is fun (and often takes some brain power to figure out how to get them), and finding and collecting all the mega tumors is a challenge. There are plenty of secrets and NPCs with interesting (but useless) dialogue. The music for the game is also amazing, providing awesome rock and metal remixes of classical songs. The End is Nigh never feels too easy or too (extremely) difficult, and the game's unique mechanics, like Ash's ability to hook onto the edges of platforms, are easy to learn and are mastered by the player easily. 

     If you are looking for a challenging but fun platformer, and you like Super Meat Boy, please, do yourself a favor and GET THIS GAME!

34876454.review: I have gotten to almost 40 hours on the game and I am about to beat it, so I decided to review it anyways because why not? The End is Nigh is easily one of the best platformer games on the market, and a spiritual successor to Super Meat Boy, which I also love. However, I wouldn't even compare this game to SMB at all except the fact that they're both platformers and are from Ed. With that said, in my opinion, TEiN combines a simpe video game with complicated cinematic style story telling. It of course has deeper meaning to be interpreted by us just as you can expect from Ed. The game features simple base mechanics, however, you can't sprint or wall jump, instead, you are highly mobile already, can hang on ledges, and have insane air control. This couples for a very interesting platforming experience, while it stays true to the base of the genre. The game isn't afraid of itself, by that I mean, it is very open about what kind of game it is, Ash, the main character, is a typical gamer guy who curses a lot. By the way, in case you didn't hear, this game takes place after the apocalypse, where Ash is the one survivor, so he doesn't have much of an audience on his livestreams, and his game cartridge crashes and he sets out to make a friend blah blah blah. Sounds pretty simple and innocent right? Nope. You will die time and time again, only to become get to the next level and repeat the same process, trust me, I have 40 hours and I'm still not done yet, so that means the game will last a while right? Anyway this game has an amazing soundtrack as well, which I can only urge you to hear for yourself to see what I mean. I give The End is Nigh a 9/10 in numbers or whatever. Thanks :)

Absolutely get this game! I thought this would be a meatboy-esque challenge but it's actually quite doable. If you don't enjoy dying over and over you're not going to have a good time though. The levels unlocked after comleting the main story can be a little frustrating.

Pros:
-Good graphics
-Areas feel unique
-Tight controls
-Good stage design, (mostly) fair gameplay
-Well-hidden and satisfying to find secrets
-Nothing is really that impossible, the difficulty spikes up a bit around the beginning but once you get used to how hard stages are after the first three it's quite managable

Cons:
-Sometimes dodging projectiles or jumping off of moving enemies is a little BS
-The hardest parts of the game, the cartridges, have the worst graphics and are the least enjoyable to play
-Backtracking and artificial difficulty everywhere. (Cough cough the tumor on golgotha 1)
-Game overs suddenly become a thing at the hardest part of the game? Really? Are you trying to lose half your players at that point?

8/10

PS. Holding down while running off a ledge makes you grab the corner. I realized this far too late. Don't be like me.

I loved Super Meat Boy but this game left me feeling like there was nothing left to do.

The game controls great, it looks great, even the level design is good (not great, I don't think), but there was no feeling of accomplishment when I beat a level.

Maybe it's because I'm not the same player I was when SMB came out, but playing this game felt like a chore. Maybe I need more story, or maybe I need to see a death replay or what, I don't know.

I don't like how some collectibles are only visible once you make it to the end; I don't like how there was a lot more waiting around for stuff to fall in this game. I didn't like the lack of unlocks; I didn't like how moving forward wasn't satisfying.

If you loved SMB as a masocore platformer, this is more of that, and well done. If you're looking for a good game overall, keep looking. This won't appeal to the same public that SMB did, even if it was well made.

34452419.review: Yet another amazing game by Edmund McMillen!

34447335.review:
The End is Nigh est le dernier jeu de Edmund Mc Millen, connu notamment pour The Binding of Isaac et Super Meat Boy.

Beaucoup, et moi le premier, ont eu peur que ce soit une redite de cet illustre dernier. Il n'en est point question ici. Super Meat Boy est un jeu très nerveux tandis que The end is Nigh est un jeu plus posé, le gameplay ne proposant pas de super sauts comme dans SMB ou niveaux à finir dans un temps donné (sauf...).

La première chose à dire est que le jeu est très, très, très difficile, voire complètement dingo par moment. Le sadisme du level design est poussé à un paroxisme qu'il m'a été rarement donné de voir. Cependant, ce jeu de plateforme est, malgré cette diffculté qui pourrait en rebuter certains,  un jeu très, très, très intelligent. En fait, aussi intelligent que sa difficulté.

The End is nigh se présente de manière classique sous forme de tableaux à traverser. Aller de la gauche vers la droite afin d'arriver au tableau suivant. L'intelligence ici se trouve dans les multiples zones cachées, l'organicité de l'ensembla des tableaux (tout se suit de manière très fluides, ont est assez loin de SMB et de ses tableau indépendants, quand bien même dans le même monde) et dans les énigmes à résoudre. Oui, des énigmes.

En effet, la difficulté de certains tableaux posent question. Et c'est à cette question qu'il faut répondre. Il faut traverser le niveau selon un certain ordre ou un autre. Chose remarquable, les "énigmes" sont donc résolvables avec différentes solutions. Bien sûr, ce n'est pas vraiment un jeu à énigmes tel qu'on pourrait le penser. Nous ne sommes pas dans un point'n'click. Néanmoins l'analogie est pertinente, surtout lorsque nous avançons dans le jeu et que celui-ci devient particulièrement ardu.

Ainsi, The End is Nigh se pose selon comme une pierre angulaire du genre, un chef d'oeuvre qu'il serait particulièrement dommageable de zapper, vu l'amour que donne les dév' à travers le jeu. De multiples zones, de multiples fins, sans parler des jeux dans le jeu (et un paquet !!!) qu'on peu trouver ça et là sous forme de cartouche à jouer dans la console au sein du jeu.

The End is Nigh est une la preuve, s'il en fallait une, que ce qu'entreprend Mc Millen devient très très souvent une tuerie. Recommandé plutôt mille fois qu'une.

Les + :

- Une durée de vie astronomique (surtout lorsqu'on est assez mauvais comme moi)
- Des tableaux qui s'enchainent organiquement
- Des tableaux cachés à foison
- Plusieurs fins
- De nombreux jeux à l'intérieur du jeu
- Un univers rigolo (Edmund semble aller très bien, merci, il a pleion de tumeurs)
- Le gameplay très fluide, se démarquant très nettement de SMB
- Lamusique génialissime, composée de plein de reprise de musique classique. Un must have. Vraiment.

Les moins :

- Une difficulté retorses pour de nombreux joueurs.
- Collecter des cancers, c'est le mal.

EN définitive, une nouvelle tuerie de Mc Millen, un must have pour tous les fans de platformer "hardcore", qui aimer jouer à des jeux qui suintent l'amour du jeu, la générosité et l'intelligence. Incontournable.

34301070.review:
This is a solid 2D platformer with a simple theme and excellent soundtrack, that is why i recommend it. 

If you like these types of games then my praise will not be effective, but I must warn you. Not adding to the other reviews here I have two HUGE problems with it.


Problem 1: 
The vast majority of levels are hard but well designed. Every main level is never too hard and you can 100% the main story quite easily. But there are some hidden levels that you can unlock known as "Cart Levels". While these are not essential (praise the lord) they are considerably harder than anything else in the game. Harder than most levels even in Super Meat Boy. 

I say this not because they require precision or reflexes. They are insanely long and unforgiving. Some people like grinding through time consuming levels over and over again until they learn not to stuff up, but fundamentally this difficulty doesn't challenge anything other than trial and error, and memory. I do not find this fun at all. If you want all of the achievements (like me) you will have to complete 10 or more stage levels in one life. Each stage may not be that hard, but doing them perfectly every time can be very stressful and dull. If you are trying to practice one life over and over again, you will have to quit the cart and enter again, which wastes a lot of time. 
Defend it however you want, I call this poor design.

Problem 2:
People seem to have a hard time explaining the difficulty of this game, comparing it to super meat boy a lot. Relative to other platformers, this is not that close to SMB. The difficulty may vary from player to player. But there are two things everyone agrees with in the end. The cart levels are what make this game extremely difficult (and the final stage, but the final stage is optional and really kind of fitting), and the difficulty spikes really fast. I consider this an underrated problem because a lot of other platformers will either : A, slowly introduce you to more and more obstacles and interactions, or B, will introduce you to the whole world at once, allowing you to explore and come back at your own pace. 

This game is neither. It is linear and branches at only two points ever. The difficulty is immediately above what i consider new players to be comfortable with. There is still a progression of difficulty  throughout the game, but it is so small it is negligible (until you reach the last few worlds where it spikes again). Being used to these kinds of games i had no problem with it, but I can easily imagine someone who starts this game with no experience at all. I'm willing to bet it wouldn't be so fun.

TL:DR 
Game = Solid
Bonus levels (cart levels) = not fun/boring
Difficulty progression = starts hard doesn't change for most of the game

34276957.review:
Overall:
If you even remotely like platformers, its worth it.
Good difficulty for everyone due to excelent design.


Good:
Very fluent controls whoch allows for precise movement; if I die, it's normally feels like my fault. I started using a controler but soon found a keyboard allowed for even more precision. Both work perfectly as controls are fully rebindable.

Beautiful art with a wide variety of worlds with different themes to cleverly avoid a repetetive field. The music is to die for, it is classical tracks with a rock inspired tone - worth picking up even if you don't want the game!

Good difficulty curve; as a decent platformer first part was fairly easy, some collectables were a bit challenging but it was enjoyable. The second part was noticably harder and the game cartiges are very hard so it is good for all skill levels.

Game runs flawlesly on my alright PC


Mixed:
Some of the hidden mega tumors are far too hidden, maybe I'm just bad but it seems a little too obscure. On the other hand there are signs and pointers to help suggest where there may be a secret.


Bad:
The story wasn't all that compelling and I found myself wanting to skip the cutscenes, this could also be because the platforming is so good.

34261839.review:
After the great Binding of Isaac The End is Nigh is the new game by Ed McNillen. It's about a post-apocalyptic world where you are a wobbling sack of meat and bones and when your favorite retro video game breaks you head out into a dangerous and hostile world to build yourself a friend from tumors that float around. 

This game will make you laugh, cry, scream, vomit and ejaculate, all at the same time.

34255495.review: Played the game for while and its difficult but fun to figure out every level and its incredibly addictive. Sound track pretty good but can get boring after a while.

34254299.review:
Reasons to buy it:
-If you'd love to play a very hard platforming game.
-If you are a masochist and love to feel pain.
-If you want to die.
-If you want to enjoy a hard but with pretty well designed levels game.
-The soundtrack is an awesome remix of some classical music songs, of which really fits the "dark" theme and atmosphere of the game.
-You loved Super Meat Boy.

Reasons to not buy it:
-You dislike hard or "stressing" platformers.
-You absolutely didn't like Super Meat Boy because it's too hardcore for you.

This game is made by Edmund McMillen (the creator of Super Meat Boy and also The Binding of Isaac) and Tyler Glaiel. This game in particular feels like a spiritual successor to Super Meat Boy, but there is no wall-jumping, instead you can hang on ledges, and while it may seem simple at first, it opens a lot of possibilities platforming-wise and gives a fair enough different feel than SMB, and also it ends up being more complex. The most difficult levels and even some achievements are considerably more difficult than Super Meat Boy, if you want a pretty challenging platforming game this may be your game. The controls feel perfect and precise, if you make a mistake, the mistake will be completely yours, no bad control design involved.

Also you collect tumors and retro game cartridges, you can play them after in your house, they feature a retro aesthetic design, with their own "retro" remix of a classical song, and most of these retro games are extremely challenging, some of them being the most difficult challenges in the game.


The game features a good amount of collectible and secrets, with various endings.
Highly recommended if you are a masochist like me.

34246082.review:
Edit: Still holds up because I want my Steam Award badge


The End Is Nigh is the first ever platformer, or game, for that matter, that I have felt strongly enough about to write a review. I will try my best to capture my impression of this game.


Pros:

The controls are top-notch. The game doesn't feel slippery or out of control like Super Meat boy did, yet it wasn't stiff either.  I'm glad Edmund opted out of wall-jump mechanics because I'm glad he didn't make this a Super Meat Boy two. The difficulty isn't that bad. It's not super hard, but it does put up a challenge if you're looking for something more in the genre. Once again, I'm happy that this wasn't a level-based game like Super Meat Boy. Some part of me is just biased towards the feel of metroidvanias and open world platformers that levelled games like SMB could never give. Finally, the soundtrack is incredible. Ridiculon manages to reinvigorate complex classical pieces with the much needed raw  instruments of the rock genre, creating something bigger than the sum of its parts. It's enough to make me want to listen to some songs that usually make me want to throw up like the Flight of the Bumblebee.


Cons:

Edmund Mcmillen is a con because he stole my fucking money.

34152898.review:
Impossible de ne pas recommander ce jeu. Edmund McMillen nous a toujours habitué à de la grande qualitée, une fois de plus, j'ai acheté sans me poser de question, et une fois de plus, je n'ais pas été déçu.
En terme d'ambiance, c'est top. Les musiques de Ridiculon sont comme toujours un régal décalé, ayant ici pour particularité d'être des reprises de morceaux classiques. L'ambiance et l'histoire sont au mausade, baigant dans l'espèce de tristesse dérangeante mélée à de l'humour chère à McMillen que l'on aime tant.
En terme de gameplay, c'est une sorte de Super Meat Boy (Bien que sans wall jump, mécanique qui régissait en partie SMB), et il faudra de la perspicacité et des réflexes pour récupérer tout les collectibles. Amis impatients et sanguins, bonsoir, il ne vous faudra pas avoir peur de recommencer encore, encore et encore les mêmes écrans. Mais vous serez récompensés par les zones secrètes et écrans cachés, en quantité très élevée, qui vous pousseront à essayer d'être plus malin que le jeu et à essayer de sortir des zones de jeu pour voir ce qu'il y a derrière.
Bref, un jeu de plateforme difficile et regorgeant de petits secrets qui sauront ravir les plus coriaces d'entre vous !

34132080.review:
The End is Nigh is a monotone platformer. The game is brutal, with thousands of deaths on the first campaign alone. The game relies on collecting tumors, 450 tumors specifically. As always, don't buy this game if you're easily offended because Golgotha (The hill where Jesus was crucified) and S.S. Exodus (A ship full of Jews which the Nazis bombed). The game controls like near flawlessly, even in the Betas. The game works as your average platformers except for how you can't wall jump and instead use hooks and ledges to scale walls. 

The bonus game carts start off easy enough (even though very few people play them) but quickly turn into hell on earth. Encountering Steven and collecting enough Tumors grants you the ability to attempt collecting an Iron cartridge. Iron cartridges are supposed to symbolize the 5 stages of grief (Helps that they're named after them) during the 4 stages of cancer (Due to tumors) and lastly, accepting death. Glitched carts are encountered in the second campaign and are better versions of normal carts. Acceptance is the final Iron cart but you'll spend days trying to beat it as it has the other four Iron carts and THEN 10 new ones.

The story is simple, your only source of entertainment just broke, now its time to venture into the apocalypse and make a friend. Sounds simple but finding a Heart, Head, and body will lead to thousands of deaths. 

I do have some problems with the game though. Acceptance is a bland way to end the Iron saga. The Future stage to collect Depression is bad. The birds are just a tad bit too fast. The machine was boring. The game doesn't even tell you that you get bonuses for not dying at all in a cartridge!

Overall I wouldn't say this game isn't perfect but I'd say this is a 7/10.

34131646.review: Ed, Isaac is good and End is Nigh is decent, but I'd really love it if you could pretty please kiss and make up with Tommy "reefer madness" Refenes and just make a proper game? Thanks dude.

34127742.review: Good. I also want to die. Never thought I would be screaming about a game's hitboxes being too precise.

34124774.review:
Наконец-то я закончил эту игру и пришло время написать обзор, так как я хочу поделиться своим мнением. Все считают, что Эдмунд МакМиллен скопировал одну из своих предыдущих игр - Супер Мит Боя. Я вижу, почему люди так думают, мне самому так казалось в первые часов пять. Прошу заметить, что мне это абсолютно не мешало наслаждаться игрой. Но потом я стал замечать, что же отличает эту игру от Мит Боя. Но об этом чуть позже.

Плюсы:
1. Сюжет. Да, тут он так же прост, как и в Мит Бое. У нашего главного героя по имени Эш сломалась его любимая и единственная игра, поэтому ему придётся покинуть своё жилище и выйти в разрушенный апокалипсисом мир. Зачем? Чтобы сделать друга. Так вот, почему же сюжет - плюс, если он так прост? Потому что хардкорному платформеру большего и не надо. Очень сложный сюжет будет отвлекать от геймплея.
2. Музыка. В Мит Бое музыку писал Дэнни Барановски и отлично справился со своей работой. Тут господа из Ridiculon решили пойти по более лёгкому пути и взять в качестве саундтрека классику. Само собой, сделав ремиксы. Но, если честно, звучит потрясающе. Покажите мне человека, которому не понравится ни одна классическая композиция.
3. Управление. Тут всё понятно, оно невероятно отзывчивое. Эш подчиняется каждому нажатию клавиши с точностью до милисекунды.

Минусы:
1. Управление. Да, управление - это также минус. Из-за такой отзывчивости порой приходится совсем легонечко нажимать на кнопку прыжка, иначе ударишься о шипы. И нужно буквально чуть-чуть задеть стик на геймпаде, если хочешь попасть в маленькую дырочку. Немного непривычно, в большинстве других игр управление не настолько отзывчивое, приходится привыкать.
2. Несколько тупых уровней, которые просто неинтересно проходить.

Различия с Мит Боем:
В плюсах и минусах я не упомянул дизайн уровней. Дело в том, что он как раз и отличает Мит Боя от The End is Nigh. В Мит Бое уровни построены так, чтобы игрок постоянно оказывался в ситуациях, в которых нужно действовать быстро и рассчитывать свои действия прямо во время выполнения предыдущих. В Мит Бое больше драйва, больше напряжённости. Может показаться, что в The End is Nigh так же, но это не так. Тут большинство уровней построены так, чтобы игрок мог легко их проходить, изначально продумав свой план действий. Я сам удивился, когда попробовал не сломя голову нестись вперёд, как в Мит Бое, а постоять и подумать, как это лучше будет проходить. Смертей стало в разы меньше. И тут гораздо больше секретных локаций, которые также нелегко найти. Серьёзно, некоторые из них очень хорошо спрятаны, можно долго сидеть и рассматривать уровень, а всё равно не заметить. Так что это больше паззловый платформер, нежели Мит Бой. Так что тут больше вкусовщина, кому что больше нравится.

Если вам хочется познакомиться с хорошим паззловым платформером с отличным левел дизайном, при этом вы не являетесь казуаром (это всё-таки достаточно сложная игра), то купите сей продукт. Свои 350 рублей Эдмунд заработал.

The End Is Nigh is A Hardish Platformer Set In A Apocalyptic Land Where Everyone May Or May Not Be Dead 
In Almost Every Level There Are Collectible Things Called Tumours, Tumours Are Used To Acess Extra Levels That May Or May Not Be Story Related (I don't know cause I cant beat them :L) 
Rather Than Getting Walljumping Instead You Get A Hook Jumping Thing, Where You Can Grab A Hook Then Jump Up Or In The Other Direction You Can Also Grab Onto The Edges Of Platforms And Do The Hook Thing
Sometimes You Will Have To Wait For Things To Collapse Or play the level Again (From The End) To Get The Tumour Or See The Exit
There Are Cartridges (Which Are Like Super Meat Boy Warpzones) You Find Them In Secret Areas In The Zones they give you 20 lives to beat 10 levels each level has 10 found which you can collect to go for an acheivement
My Only Complaint Is There's No Level System If You Are In The Middle Of A Zone Then Decide To Go To A Different Zone Your Gonna Have To Play That Whole Zone Again And If You Miss A Tumour and Want To Go Get It Your Gonna Have To Do It From The Start
