34063283.review:
A superb platformer. Outstanding level/world design that has more in common with a metroidvania than a standard platformer. I really feel like there is a puzzle element to the platforming in this game but it's quite hard to describe, it's just not like any other platformer i've played in the best way possible. A great OST made up of classical music variations helps build the tension on the harder screens and just fit's really well with the gameplay. There is also a LOT of content here, i'm 16 hours in and not even close to having everything done. It should go without saying that this is a pretty hard game also, some of the levels make the hardest parts of Super Meat Boy look like a cakewalk. Speaking of Super Meat Boy, The End is Nigh controls like an absolute dream.

You like jumping into spikes? Buy it.

34057390.review:
The End Is Nigh is a adventure platformer game collaboration between Edmund McMillen and Tyler Glaiel where Edmund draws most of the art and Tyler writes most of the programing. 

[h1] Comparison to Super Meat Boy [/h1]
One of the first things that people talk about right away with this game is how it compares to Super Meat Boy. I haven't played much of Super Meat Boy, but I don't think it's a fair comparison because despite them both being platformers that Edmund helped to create, they offer very different playstyles to the player. Super Meat boy is fast and requires a lot more reflex than The End Is Nigh. Ash is less slippery than Meat Boy and doesn't have the wall jump. The few things that this game does have in common with Edmund's other platformer are Edmund's art style, high difficulty, Good controls, and a rocking soundtrack.

[h1] Story [/h1]
This game takes place after an unexplained apocalypse that destroyed the world leaving only most of Ash and a few other survivors alive. Ash is first seen playing a game cartridge before it breaks which causes him to start screaming "F♥CK" until he calms down. He decides that now is the time to go and "Make a friend" which involves gathering three parts and putting them together. In order to get those parts Ash has to leave his home and go out and explore the world.

[spoiler] Ash puts his friend together and has a great time with it. The semi-sentient corpse is implied to have drugged Ash and started a second apocalypse while Ash was asleep. When he wakes up, he has to confront his friend about this betrayal. [/spoiler]

[spoiler] When Ash finally arrives deep within the Earth he finds his friend attached to a giant glowing orb. He decides that it's time for them to split ways and then has to escape from the orb before it ends the world a third time. Unfortunately for Ash, even if he does manage to escape he is consumed by the explosion and is killed. [/spoiler]

[h1] Gameplay [/h1] 

[b] Platforming [/b]
Ash controls really well and feels nice to move around. At no point in this game did I ever feel like I didn't have full control of Ash's movement ([spoiler]not even during those last few stages in Ruin that had gravity pulling ash to the left[/spoiler]). Even in the water and in the air you can move Ash left and right or use the trigger to force him to fall faster. The control being good is important because in this game you are going to die [i] a lot [/i]. Most of the time your goal is just simply to get to the other side of the stage without dying. You could also go after tumors but even then the goal is still to get them and then leave the stage. The kind of obstacles that Ash will face are spikes, lava, projectiles, and enemies. All of these of course kill Ash on contact. Dying just places you back where you entered the level and the levels in this game aren't very long so you only lose a few seconds of progress every time you die which encourages you to try again and again until you can finish it. Sometimes you will have to look before you leap and take a moment to think about how you're going to go through the stage before you start running in because you don't want to be stuck avoiding projectiles while you think of the next place you have to jump to. It feels very methodical because there are lots of times where you can only barely make a jump and you have to know [i] how [/i] to pull it off before you actually pull it off. 

[b] Tumors [/b]
Tumors are the collectable of this game. There is one in just about every level in every world with a total of 450 collectable tumors. Tumors are usually placed in spots that are harder to get to and add a bit of an extra challenge to the stage if you decide to bother collecting them. Collecting a tumor doesn't add it to your total tumor count right away since it requires that you exit the stage without dying or have to get the tumor again. It's not until about 3/4s into the game that tumors actually benefit you in anyway. Once [spoiler] your friend betrays you [/spoiler] tumors will function as a life count and you will lose one life every time you die which will result in a game over that sends you back to the beginning of the world you lost your last life in. They are replenished as soon as you exit the worlds where this is active or when you use a warp point. If you collect a certain number of tumors you can find "Steven"s scattered throughout the game that allow you to see the future. There are four future levels and each one of them offers a special game cartridge when you finish it.

[b] Cartridges [/b]
There is one hidden in every world. You can play these on Ash's TV and they're pretty much more of the main game but in low-bit and with challenges like collect all of the coins or complete it without using a continue. They offer bonus tumors if you finish them and you can get up to an additional 52 tumors which will push your save file completion over 100% if you already have the 450 tumors that are in the worlds.

[b] World Design [/b]
Just as the steam tags imply this is an adventure platformer which means that there will be to at least some degree some exploration and platforming. Worlds are seperated into 16-20 "levels" with a warp point at the start of each world allowing you to travel to any previously visited warp points. I call them levels but each level is connected to the last and in some worlds you can skip some levels or you might have to come back to a level but from a different entry point in order to reach someplace that you couldn't get to before. The worlds themselves are also conncted to each other and will eventually come to a split where you can branch off into three different world pathways. This is in my opinion the biggest factor that seperates The End Is Nigh from Super Meat Boy- the open world. Each world contains secret areas with mega tumors that are worth five tumors each and cartridges. You can usually find secret areas by looking for a falling block, a lone ledge stub, fake walls, or a seemingly bottomless pit that doesn't seem like it belongs there. Most worlds also have locked doors which you require you to get a key from somewhere else and then return to that world once you have a spare key. Besides gathering collectables the secret areas also allow you to interact with more NPCs which can offer funny dialogue or a small bit of insight into the world. 

[h1] Soundtrack [/h1]
The whole soundtrack is rock covers of classical music. Holy fuck. 
It sounds really good and I reccomend you give it a listen and consider buying it from [url=https://ridiculon.bandcamp.com/album/the-end-is-nigh-ost] Ridiculon's Bandcamp [/url] so you can get the BONUS BONUS song if you pay exactly $6.66.

33969293.review:
The End Is Nigh. oh boi con The End Is Nigh.

es un juego de Edmund, 99/10.

[i]ok, empecemos con la critica de verdad[/i]

-el estilo artistíco es el tipico de nuestro amigo edmundo, macabro y kawaii a la vez, no hay mucho que decir acerca de este aspecto

-los controles, yo e jugado con mando de xbox y no e probado a jugar con teclado, pero estos juegos son siempre mejores con mando, el control del personaje es PERFECTO, se mueve exactamente como quieres y como debe, así que aquí no vale echarle la culpa al mando ;). el arsenal de moviemientos de ash (el prota) es simple: te mueves, saltas, y al estar pegado a un borde o un gancho, te agarras automaticamente.

- el diseño de niveles es muy bueno y muchas veces ingenioso, y lo más importante, no hay pantallas injustas, esto sumado al echo de que el control es impecable hace que perder sea siempre tu culpa, lo cual es genial, nunca hay cosas que te matan de manera aleatoria, practicamente todos los enemigos siguen un patrón simple, e incluso los enemigos que no siguen un patron en concreto no son injustos gracias al diseño del nivel.

-en este juego hay un coleccionable que son los tumores (si, has leído bien, tumores) los cuales muchas veces hacen que los niveles cobren más dificultad por el simple echo de que estás emperrao a conseguir los tumores, [b]y hazme caso, quieres esos tumores[/b]

-mecanicas, una de las mecanicas principales, aparte de agarrase a los bordes y ganchos, es que este juego es un mundo abierto dividido en pantallas (lleno de secretos además) por lo que habrá tumores que se consiguen desde la siguiente pantalla, o simplemente puedes entrar y salir para reaparecer por el lado que entras al morir y facilitarte el conseguir tumorcitos, cada mundo tiene su tematica y sus mecanicas unicas, en cada uno de los mundos, y nunca deja de sorprender.

-la musica: veamos, te gusta el rock? te gustan las obras clasicas? [spoiler]PUES AUNQUE NO TE GUSTEN PREPÁRATE PORQUE LA BANDA SONORA DE ESTE JUEGO DEJARÁ TU ROPA INTERIOR HÚMEDA[/spoiler] ahora enserio, la banda sonora es posiblemente de lo mejorcito que escuchado, hace no mucho estuve jugando a una pantalla super dificil mirando a la pantalla como un zombie y tarareando la musica.

-dificultad, una cosa importante, el juego. es.[u]D I F í C I L[/u] pero nunca injusto, así que prepárate, este juego te va a poner a prueba muuchas veces y sin piedad.

-resumiendo, un grandioso plataformas, si te gustó super meat boy o isaac, o simplemente quieres un juego desafiante o un plataformas, comprálo, yo solo diré que este el primer juego que e precomprado en mi vida.

33959303.review:
I've greatly enjoyed "The End Is Nigh".  Like all of Edmunds games, it is blisteringly hard, but for the most part fair.  There are a few design choices I found questionable.  For example the Iron Cart Retro Levels (Denial, Anger, etc.) are a bit too unforgiving in their lack of lives.  And the obstacles in the bonus levels where you obtain those carts can be difficult to tell from the floor itself in some places.  And if you go for collecting everything, some of the jumps and manuevers you are expected to pull off can be downright infuriating, to the point where you don't feel any achievement in suceeding in those parts, just the hollowness that follows rage.  Still, those instances are few and far between, and the game more than makes up for it in atmosphere and music (seriously the music is amazing).

One final note: this is NOT Super Meat Boy 2.  While it shares some aspects, the core philosophy is entirely different.  SMB for the most part emphasized flying around the level, pulling off acrobatic stunts in order to obtain the fastest time.  The End Is Nigh is very much the opposite, in that it usually requires you to take your time and manuevere through tight spaces.  It is still fun, but in a very different way.  So if you are expecting SMB 2, you might be disappointed.

33951146.review:
Bought this at most 3 days ago, writing this review as of 12.7 hours played and having beaten the main story with only 1 true ending left to get I feel I can give some decent insight.

This is similar to Super Meat Boy, there's no running and no wall jumping/sliding involved and your character doesn't gain new abilities as he goes, the game just makes you aware at certain points what combining buttons does and how your character can interact with the world. 

Honestly I love the main character, the platforming isn't stupid hard and the achievements are alright for the most part, collecting tumors (collectibles) is necessary for later game, they do make you aim for higher skills though so be warned some are tough cookies to get.

The game does have a spike in difficulty, at points it is very mild and at others it does feel hard and like you don't want to do it as much, sometimes as a result of "how in the F am I supposed to do this!?" and sometimes it is because the enemy AI on a few particular enemies is too good, it feels that way but having gone through said levels again it was just me.

You have cartridges to collect in this, they're completely optional and beyond letting you play the old retro games and giving you bonus tumors for beating certain achievements they are not needed UNLESS you want the true ending. Sure that sounds like a deal breaker but honestly for how hard it'll be to get the true ending anyway you probably will be happy enough getting the normal 1 first.

I consider myself decent at platformers, despite my 12.7 hours (so far) I have died roughly 4K times and counting every time I boot it up. Will be nice to go for the under 200 deaths as I feel I have a good grasp of everything now and believe me there is plenty to keep you occupied if you wish.

Overall this game is a bargain and having paid full price I don't have any regrets, sitting at 20 ish achievements and tons left to do I feel this was worth the price I paid. If you enjoy platformers without gimmicks and just skill involved then you'll love this, the soundtrack is pretty damn awesome too!

33916508.review:
I once said that never a game made me cry so badly as Super Hexagon. 
Now I can take it back.

Now for the actual review: Even with just 5 hours of gameplay and only 6 worlds unlocked (that's 17% of the game) I can say that this is harder than SMB.

Not exactly the same gameplay. Where SMB gave you time to think and plan, The End is Nigh gives you no time at all. The game begins easy, but by the 3rd world you're shaking, crying and cursing Mr McMillen and Mr Glaiel. A LOT.

The game features the same kind of small levels, one screen after another, like SMB or Isaac. But unlike SMB (or Isaac) you have little to NO TIME to think. In further levels, most of the time you'll have less than 2 seconds to think before you die. 

AND YOU'LL DIE. AND YOU'LL CRY. AND YOU'LL RAGE QUIT. A LOT.

But don't let the data above bother you. It's a great game. I dare to say that's even better than SMB in terms of challenge and fun.

Other than that, you can expect the same mechanics from SMB. Extra levels, extra challenges, collectables that unlock stuff, you know the drill.

Go for it. Buy it full price, it's worth every cent.

(Oh, I'm playing this on my keyboard, as I hate controllers. Perfectly doable.)

33895075.review:
슈미보에 이은 맥밀런의 하드코어 플랫포머 게임. 하다보면 게임의 메인 컨텐츠가 캐릭터를 죽이는건가 싶다. (작성자 본인은 플레이타임 기준 10초에 1번꼴로 죽었다. 카트리지 올 클리어에 도전중이므로 더 늘어날 예정...)

슈미보와 마찬가지로 조작감은 훌륭하다. 다만 저사양 컴퓨터의 경우 해상도나 쉐이더 등을 낮춰야 한다. 일부 맵에서 렉이 걸릴 수 있다. 프레임만 제대로 나오면 환상적인 컨트롤과 환장할 난이도를 같이 느낄 수 있다. [strike]프레임 드랍이 일어나면 후자만 겪겠지 뭐..[/strike]


슈미보와 비슷한 점들은 다음과 같다.

- 난이도. 둘 다 어렵다. 다만 굳이 따지자면 이게 더 어렵다.

- 조작감이 좋다.

- 게임 디자인. 슈미보와 마찬가지로 각 스테이지들의 메인플로우가 있고, 그 사이사이에 숨겨진 서브 스테이지가 껴있는 방식이다.

그 중 일부는 스테이지를 "수집하는" 방식인데, 이들은 고전게임을 패러디한 레트로 그래픽 스테이지라는 점도 같다.



다른점은 다음과 같다.

- 스테이지의 연결. 슈미보는 스테이지 각각을 클리어한다는 거라면, TEIN은 연결된 스테이지를 지나간다는 느낌이다.

때문에 숨겨진 스테이지를 찾는 방식도 약간 다르다. 이 게임은 다소 거칠게 말하자면 어떻게든 갈 수 있는 곳을 찾아 비집고 들어간다는 느낌으로 찾아야 한다.

그리고 슈미보는 스테이지를 선택할 수 있지만, TEIN은 챕터만 선택할 수 있고 세부 스테이지까지 이동시켜주진 않는다. 각 스테이지마다 슈미보의 반창고 격인 종양(tumor)가 있는데, 먹지 못하고 지나갈 경우 그 챕터의 1스테이지부터 다시 찬찬히 지나가면서 그걸 먹어야 한다..

- 조작감의 차이. 물론 둘 다 좋은 조작감이지만, TEIN이 슈미보보다 덜 미끄러진다. 그리고 슈미보의 벽점에는 특별한 제약이 없었지만, 이 게임에서는 특수한 곳에 "달라붙기"를 한 다음 벽점이 가능하다. 그 외에는 점프 후 아래키를 눌러 빠른 하강이 가능하다는 점. 후반부에 꽤 중요한 스킬이다.

- 일부 수집요소의 차이. 슈미보는 일부 스테이지에 반창고가 있지만 TEIN은 매 스테이지마다 앞서 말한 종양이 있다. 그리고 숨겨진 스테이지에는 종양 5개에 해당되는 대형 종양(MEGA TUMOR) 또는 수집형 스테이지인 카트리지가 있다. 대형 종양은 일반 종양과 마찬가지로 "수집 후 스테이지 이동"까지 해야 완전한 수집으로 인정하지만, 카트리지는 그냥 먹기만 해도 인정한다.

카트리지의 종류도 여러가지인데, 공통적으로 카트리지에 미션이 달려있다. 미션 1개당 총 종양 수가 1개씩 증가한다. 자세한건 직접 플레이하면서 알아가는 것을 추천한다.

- 그 외에는 브금이 클래식을 어레인지한 점, 그리고 캐릭터가 1개라는 점[spoiler], 엔딩이 2개라는 점[/spoiler]이 있다.



이런류의 어려운 게임을 좋아하는 [strike]마조히스트[/strike]게이머들이라면 매우 재밌게 플레이할 수 있는 갓겜이다. 사전예약으로 구매한 게임인데, 원가로 사도 그 이상의 가치를 갖는 게임이다.

P.S. 벽에 매달리는 조작이 아래+좌/우 방향키인데, 꾹 눌러도 잘 매달린다. 본인은 이런줄 모르고 불안해서 굳이 점프해서 붙으려다 데스 수만 늘었다..

[spoiler]P.S.S. 시작할 때 인트로 격으로 하게되는 스테이지를 잘 기억해라. 아마 나중에 만날수ㄷ 읍읍!![/spoiler]

33876545.review:
A lot of people have called The End is Nigh "Super Meat Boy 2". I somewhat agree. It definitely has a similar aesthetic and certain elements are reminiscient of SMB. It's closer to Super Meat Boy than Edmund's other games, with its precision jumps and retro stages, certain obstacles and collectibles. It will certainly keep you busy for a few days, and far longer if you aim for some of the more ridiculous challenges or achievement hunting.

Sitting at 99% completion on my main save file, I think it goes without saying I've enjoyed the game quite a bit. I like the level design and hunting down secrets. I've both adored and loathed the retro stages and I don't think I can leave this game unfinished, even if some of the iron man challenges are sure to give me a hard time.

While I recommend this game to any fans of SMB and difficult platformers, I think it's best to get some of the negative aspects out of the way early on. 

The gameplay is quite self-explanatory. You jump, grab ledges and wall hooks and make your way from one screen to the next. While the controls are tight, grabbing some of the ledges feels like pixel hunting. If you miss, you hit a spike. Since most every jump has been "optimized" in a way that you can reach areas without too much hassle, this feels either like an oversight or artificially inflated difficulty.

Most screens have tumors as collectibles, and some of them make you go an extra mile before finishing the level. However, some of them are locked out of your reach if you enter the next screen, forcing you to replay several levels again. Once again, this falls under artificial gameplay inflation. And while on the topic of collectibles, if you grab one and exit the screen, you've obtained it. This means you can pick up a tumor, backtrack to the previous screen and THEN beat the stage. This makes some of the levels slightly more tolerable, but I find it slightly off-putting.

That's the bad out of the way. A lot of people have posted complaints about certain enemies being unpredictable (see: Thistle Fish) and therefore unfair, but that's simply not true. As far as I'm aware, there's a pattern to everything and if you haven't figured it out, that's on you. That doesn't mean some enemies and areas aren't relentlessly difficult, but they all have a discernible attack pattern. Well, maybe aside from the birds.

Just about everything else about this game I like. The controls are tight, there's no vsync delay, the soundtrack is a well-rendered heavy metal/8-bit mixture of classical pieces, the graphics look nice (and remind me of SMB on several occasions). Most rooms are enjoyable to play and hunting down secrets is mostly fun. The few abilities (such as dashing downwards) you have from the start are revealed as the game progresses, which means you'll probably miss out on something your first time through, but on subsequent playthroughs you know immediately how to utilize them. This is unlike metroidvania games where you hunt down abilities first and then return to previous areas. Personally I think it was a refreshing touch.

I suppose difficulty needs to be discussed. At frst I thought The End was more difficult than SMB. Having beaten the core game (and then some) I'm not too sure about that anymore. Some areas are relentless. Certain retro carts are a bastard and a half. And some secrets took me way more tries than I'd like to admit. But not once did I find myself wanting to throw my controller at a wall. Therefore I wouldn't call this an unreasonable difficult "masocore" game. But unless you're well-versed in platformers and like more difficult than average games, this might not be the game for you.

My 5 cents above are written at 29 hours of gameplay and a 99% savefile. Whether this game stands the test of time remains to be seen, but at any rate, it's definitely kept me entertained so far and I'm looking forward to beating it again.

33876514.review:
So, here we are. Super Meat Boy 2! Oh wait...nevermind. It is in no way a sequel to Meat Boy nor related to it in any way. But, that is one of the reasons why i like this game.
On a graphical standpoint, levels have a simple but pretty interesting design, as well as detail.
Controls are pretty light and straightforward. However, the difficulty progression in the game seems to know no boundaries. By the time you reach The Future set of levels, everything changes. Difficulty basically jumps up a bunch and it keeps on getting harder, especially in secret areas. If you're somewhat familiar with game's mechanics - you more than likely won't end up looking at Game Over screen, since for some reason, your lives will have a limit from then on. Same applies to cart games. At least though, you can afford to take your time, which i appreciate.
As for the story, let's just say that a game such as this doesn't really need one, but it has its moments nevertheless. I am not a fan of Ash's background though, however, it doesn't affect experience.
In overall, game offers a lot of interesting and tricky levels for you to enjoy, secrets, as well as achievements. It is indeed a good challenge, even though it's frustrating from time to time and from a certain point in the game, most of it will be just trial and error.
To anyone who cares: if you value your sanity but still wanna try this game, i would recommend starting with Super Meat Boy, to get the idea of how the challenge is and how the difficulty would be progressing.

Oh Mcmillen, you've done it again.
After the, let's go with, troubled release of Binding of Isaac Afterbirth Plus, I began to lose faith, no pun intended.

And then you released The End is Nigh, and completely brought it all back.  I've put more time and effort into your games than I would like to admit, over 2,000 hours in Binding of Isaac Rebirth alone, and, for the most part, have completed them to a large extent.  The End is Nigh looks to be no different.  And while the game may be great as always, and hard as nails in some of the later sections (there is a lives system in place for the latter half of the game, however, it can be mitigated through the playing of the first half), the real reason I was blown away by this game is the soundtrack.  For the most part, it's a remix of classic symphonies, Flight of the Bees, the 1812 overture, etc, done to heavy rock, to great success.  Marche Slave, in particular, brought back some memories.

If you like anything that McMillen does, you'll like this.

33840385.review:
As another game by Edmund McMillen, this game does not disappoint in his most attractive areas: Ambiguous story, strange cast of characters, and simple yet entertaining writing. On those points alone this game is worth $15, to support Edmund and to enjoy a quirky platformer.

As a platformer however, this is the most enjoyable platformer I've played in recent memory, including Super Meat Boy, another game of Edmund's. The difficulty in this game steadily ramps up throughout its many areas, past the point I thought it would stop. The mini collectables found in most levels are a fun challenge that rewards perceptive players. The larger collectables hidden behind secret walls or difficult platforming, are even more satisfying. The game's 1st half is hard, but accessible enough for most players to work their way through, though the 2nd half is brutal, challenging all players who dare proceed. If you succeed and beat the game, another "ending" area is available that is even more challenging. Finally, there are the game cartridges unlocked as collectables that comprise the "end game" of The End Is Nigh. Each chapter in the game contains a game cartridge that is much more difficult, and there are some other cartridges that, while slightly bullshit, are also challenges worth facing.

All in all this game ended up interesting me much more than I would've thought possible and I don't plan on quitting until I've done all there is. If you're interested, this game is also a very viable game for speedrunning as the game goes as fast as you do, and there are no random elements to worry about. Getting through the game relies solely on your skill.

33833149.review:
I didn't love Super Meat Boy.  The game had its fun, rewarding levels here and there, but it was brought down by being too fast to react to anything, too slippery in the air for reliable jumps, and too full of hard-to-manage enemies and obstacles which made many levels feel more like luck than a test of skill.  A few of the boss fights relied solely on memorization, some challenges were excessively long with no checkpoints, the jump button didn't even always register, and I could spend half an hour getting a successful run of a stage and still not have done it fast enough for an A+ rank, which destroyed any interest I had in 100%ing the game.

The End is Nigh fixes every issue I had with Super Meat Boy.

This game has a moderately more relaxed pace, with far tighter, less variable movement.  The jump button is responsive every time and feels exactly the way it should.  There are no timers, and hanging on ledges is a suitable replacement for wall-jumping because it allows you to sit still and analyze the area methodically.  And you start out with your full moveset, but you learn how in-depth it is throughout the game.

Every screen is a checkpoint, and depending on how you enter an area, you'll have a different respawn point, making certain collectables more convenient and fair to obtain while still posing a challenge.  Most (but certainly not all) of this game's difficulty comes from the optional parts, which I consider to be very good design.

This game has no boss fights; it doesn't need any, because the environment is harsh enough.  What it does have are some tricky enemies to avoid (or use to your advantage), which are not always easy to deal with, but their patterns are reliable enough to manage.  The mechanics in this game also never seem to fall into the wretchedly physics-oriented hive that Super Meat Boy's air currents or repelling magnets did.

On top of all that, I'd even say TEiN has the better artwork, music, story, and characters.

The backgrounds are often monochromatic, fairly saturated cityscapes or skies against the silhouetted terrain our charming protagonist Ash explores.  Everything is slick and smooth, as opposed to strangely polygonal like much of Meat Boy's art.  There is more depth to be found in Ash's simple post-apocalyptic tale of woe and the odd little messages from the dead than there is in rescuing Bandage Girl from a fetus in a jar.  The music is comprised almost entirely of hardcore rock covers of famous classical music, which is frankly just a recipe for success.  It's the kind of soundtrack I want to listen to while I'm working to increase my productivity.

So far, I've completed 80% of the game and intend to see it through to the end.  It might not be as nigh as it seems.

Now, I've seen others say this game has no soul, and that it's somehow lazy.  But even in its world of skulls and corpses, there's a heartbeat.  This game is no less meticulously designed than anything Edmund has crafted, and I'd argue that it is his best work.

33823568.review:
Super Meatboy 2? Kind of. As fun as Meat 1? Yep! 

The platforming requires nimble fingers and accurate timing without the speed demanded from Meat. This game requires a slightly more methodical approach. Yes, the infrastructure is similar (with cool little "split" twists) - You have main worlds with 1-screen sub levels to complete. The controller input is just as tight; however, the wall grab mechanic has been replaced by a corner grab.  The music, in my opinion, is very appropriate and defintely cool, as was Meat. The story is just as dark as Meat.

The one main con I had throughout the game was there were no main level bosses. That could have been really cool with the mechanics and level design at play. Maybe Team Meat will release a DLC with just that - boss levels! Wink, wink! 

In summary, this is a more than adequate successor to Super Meatboy. Fun collectibles, huge challenge curve in late game for those fans of hard-as-nails platformers! Buy it! 

[spoiler]Warning: The true ending with the timer is hard as balls...but oh so worth it once finished. Don't know yet if I regard it as fair... [/spoiler]

33788518.review:
[h1]Video Review[/h1]

https://youtu.be/Dc8ybI9mhaM

[h1]Quick Info[/h1]

[i]The End is Nigh[/i] is a great addition to the precision platformer genre alongside games like [i]Super Meat Boy[/i] and [i]They Bleed Pixels[/i]. It doesn’t strictly follow either formula. It forges its own path by incorporating more rush mechanics the require quick and precise movements out of the player. While the narrative is lacking, that didn’t hurt the game all too much, although it would have made the experience all the more unique if the narrative had been stronger. If you like difficult platforming, [i]The End is Nigh[/i] will definitely give you that fix.

For more info watch the video above or read the whole review at: [url=https://vinrafel.blogspot.com/2017/…/review-end-is-nigh.html]Vinrafel[/url]

33784121.review:
Was soll man sagen?

Fangen wir vielleicht erstmal damit an:
Nein, es ist kein Super Meatboy Nachfolger! Die einzigen Ähnlichkeiten die das Spiel mit Super Meatboy hat sind der Artstyle, dass es ein 2D-Plattformer und extrem schwer ist. Mehr aber auch nicht. Wer sich hier also einen richtigen Nachfolger von Super Meatboy gewünscht hat, der ist bei diesem Spiel leider falsch.

Das heißt aber nicht, dass es schlecht ist! Ganz im gegenteil! 

Doch welche Unterschiede gibt es zu Super Meatboy?
Erstmal kann man weder sprinten noch richtig anj Wänden springen. Das geht nämlich nur an Ecken und Haken. Das sprinten ist aber auch tatsächlich unnötig, da man auch so schnell genug ist. Und seid mal ehrlich:
Habt ihr jemals in Super Meatboy den Finger von dem rechtem Trigger genommen?
Das mit den Wall Jumps ist tatsächlich gar nicht so schlimm und man gewöhnt sich ziemlich schnell dran, dass es keine gibt.

Aber kommen wir mal zu den Levels:
Sie sind alle schön kurz, so wie es in Super Meatboy, abgesehen von den Bosslevels, von denen es in The End is Nigh bis jetzt übrigens bei mir noch keine gab, auch war. Sie sind allerdings allen nicht wirklich schwer. Die Schwierigkeit liegt nämlich nicht direkt am Level, sondern wie man das Level löst und gleichzeitig den Tumor (Tumore sind in diesem Spiel die Sammelobjekte, von denen es in so gut wie jedem Level einen gibt) einsammelt. Die Tumore direkt beim ersten Versuch das Level zu schaffen ist übrigens nur zu empfehlen, da man die einzelnen Level später nicht wieder einzeln auswählen kann, sonder direkt alle vorherigen Level erneut spielen muss. Es gibt nämlich KEINE Level auswahl. Man kann sich nur zu den einzelnen Welten teleportieren. Das ist allerdings gar nicht schlimm, da die Level alle recht schaffbar sind, wenn man den Tumor schon hat.

Ich muss sagen, das Spiel ist super und für jeden, der Super Meatboy gespielt hat und nichts gegen diese "Änderungen" hat, ein Muss! Ich persönlich muss jedoch sagen, dass ich es eher gelegentlich spiele und nicht mit einem Mal durch. Ändert jedoch nichts an der Tatsache, dass das Spiel ein echt guter 2D-Plattformer ist! :)

33770570.review:
What happens when you take spewer, give it gish's mechanics,throw it in the world of SMB, boil it in gamer's tears, and give it a pinch of salt? You get this game.

The end is nigh is a precision platformer that seems to be an extension of a lot of Ed's previous platformers. The comparisons to meat boy are inevitable so I'll address the elephant in the room.

-This game's overall look is similar to that of meat boy's, but it's more polished.
-Some of the enemies and hazards return in the form of something else.
-The dark world and warp zones return to some extent.
-The difficulty is up to par with meat boy
However, this game is by no means a sequel to super meat boy, and that's not what we should expect going into it imo.

[h1] Pros : [/h1]

-Ash's controls are tight, fast, and responsive.
-The areas are detailed and do a good job setting in the atmosphere.
-The soundtrack is fantastic, and definitely adds to the environment.
-Almost all collectibles are obtainable from the get go, which lessens the pain of backtracking.
-The level design is great
-This game favors exploration and keeping your eyes peeled for secrets, the room-to-room style of progression from most of ed's games is removed in favor of a gauntlet of levels.
-This game can challenge people of pretty much any skill level, the difficulty can surpass meat boy at times.
-this game does a good job of teaching you how it works.
-despite an extreme amount of deaths, (I have 6000+ after beating the full main game, not including nevermore). This game doesn't seem as rage inducing as meat boy, at least not until the [strike]Warp zones[/strike] end game bonus content. 

[h1] Cons : [/h1]
-Some of the jumps require almost pixel perfect accuracy and timing, which can result in trial and error.
-most of the enemies are [b]A N N O Y I N G[/b] and can definitely hinder the experience, this can be lessened by paying attention to their patterns though.
-There are some really annoying hazards in this game as well, such as polluted air.
-Some of the collectibles are very poorly placed, but most of them are clever.
-There is a distinct lack of bosses in this game, which is a shame because there was more of a focus on enemies this time around. The climax is still pretty good though.
-sometimes the gripping mechanic can work against you.
-The story is nothing to write home about.


Overall, I really enjoyed this game and preferred it over super meat boy, I can reccomend this game to any precision platformer fan.

33750224.review: Brutally difficult, but not in a bad way. The controls are extremely precise and the platforming feels great, but expect to die a lot. In about 3 hours of playtime, I've died upwards of 500 times. But that's not bad. It's a good challenge, and sometimes overwhelming in later areas, but extremely satisfying when you do complete a difficult stage. On top of the already-solid game, there are countless secret areas and hidden goodies, allowing for decent replay value. The atmosphere is bleak yet somewhat optimistic, with the tone being set by a lovely intro and retained by a beautiful art style and soundtrack. Every piece of music in the game is an alternate take on a classical piece (for instance, many cave areas play "In the Hall of the Mountain King". A nod to Manic Miner, perhaps?)

Excelente juego, muy divertido y frenético. Pensaba que iba a ser como un Super Meat Boy (SMB) 2, pero es bastante diferente la jugabilidad. Un ejemplo claro es la dificultad: En SMB la dificultad sube poco a poco, pero en The End is Nigh se produce un corte entre lo fácil y difícil cuando pasas "The Past" y vas a "The Future". Otra cosa que me agrada mucho es que haya un coleccionable por sala y las salas secretas. Lo único que no me gustó del juego fue:
-Que en algunas salas secretas, cuando te caes, como estás encima de otra sala, en vez morir caes a otra sala como pasa con el primer secreto de "The Machine" que si te caes vuelves a "Retrogade".
-En sí mismo el nivel "The Machine", es MUUUUUUUUUUY molesto ya que es un laberinto insoportable con salas muy molestas y tediosas.
- (ALERTA DE SPOILER )Esto ya es cosa mía, pero seguro a alguien más le pasó... En "Acceptance" cuando te queda poco tiempo (1 minuto, 40 segundos exactamente), la pantalla empieza a vibrar de una manera exagerada y el  destello blanco de la bola gigante de energía se intensifica y molesta demasiado. Estas dos cosas hacen que te pongas muy nervioso y, en mi caso, failear en los últimos 3 niveles (especialmente en el nivel 3, que es bastaaaaante difícil)



Otra cosa es que para mí Super Meat Boy y The End is Nigh están súper conectados. Recuerden que al final del capítulo 4 "Hell" en SMB, Dr. Fetus explota una bomba que destruye todo y acaba con toda vida existente en la Tierra, dando lugar al capítulo siguiente "The Rapture"... CASUALMENTE Ash vive en un edificio destruido y básicamente todo el primer capítulo de The End is Nigh, "The End" es en una ciudad cayéndose a pedazos, además cuando estas en The Future y quieres ir a The Past mediante el mapa, se ve dibujada una bomba atómica.

Somehow Edmund has managed to make his hardest game yet. The lack of wall jumping/double jumping/aerial movement options means every single jump needs to be calculated and masterful.

The last few stages are incredibly hard. If you are finding stage 3 impossible, you may never finish this game without fortitude and courage, for the mechanics of stage 3 are only the tip of the iceburg.

And collecting the bonuses? A lot of them require seriously complicated execution and tackling the levels in ways you didn't think were possible. Then there are the bonus levels (cartridges) that have their own hard challenges attached, let alone just beating them.

Absolutely a must-have for the person who enjoys the brutal platforming genre. Really enjoying the challenge of this one. Worth every penny.

33722749.review:
(...)

Em The End is Nigh, o jogador controla Ash, um dos únicos sobreviventes do apocalipse. Ash passa os dias trancado em seu quarto, jogando videogames. Mas, quando seu cartucho se torna defeituoso, Ash decide sair em busca de um amigo. Para montar um amigo, Ash precisa de uma cabeça, um corpo e um coração. Para conseguir isso, Ash terá que atravessar o mundo destruído, cheio de criaturas, espinhos, prédios desmoronando, água corrosiva, lâminas giratórias… não existe limite para a criatividade de McMillen quando o objetivo é criar perigos para os jogadores.

(...)

Mais do que a característica de um bom jogo de plataforma, controles acurados são essenciais para sobreviver nos jogos de McMillen. Isso porque cada fase exige um tempo rápido de resposta e precisão milimétrica do jogador. A memória muscular é essencial para progredir no clássico de 2010 e no título mais recente.

The End is Nigh também é dividido em fases. Fases principais, que se agrupam em mundos. Fases secretas, acessadas em caminhos alternativos. E fases ainda mais secretas, que se abrem depois que determinada exigência é cumprida no jogo principal. Ao longo das fases, também é possível coletar objetos específicos, que exigem ainda mais capacidade de planejamento e adaptação do jogador. É até redundante dizer que a morte está presente no centro da jogabilidade, e que é possível morrer centenas de vezes em poucas horas. 

(...)

A ideia de fases retrô, ou de fases baseadas em outros jogos, introduzida em Super Meat Boy, foi ampliada em The End is Nigh. Existem cartuchos colecionáveis espalhados pelo mundo, e cada cartucho habilita um novo jogo a partir do videogame de Ash. O princípio da plataforma também é o que guia esses minigames, mas cada cartucho habilita novos desafios. Com novas formas de morrer. Isso significa que mesmo os amantes mais experientes da plataforma têm muito trabalho pela frente, caso desejem chegar ao final do jogo e ver tudo o que The End is Nigh reserva. E para os que não possuem reflexos de plataforma tão aguçados, como a Mãe, podem esperar dezenas de horas até conseguir chegar ao primeiro final.

(...)

Para além da jogabilidade, The End is Nigh é um dos jogos mais bonitos lançados nos últimos meses. Não porque possua gráficos brilhantes e reluzentes, mas porque todas suas características estéticas trabalham em harmonia para construir o panorama pretendido. O traço simples dos desenhos não atrapalha em nada na criação de cenários variados, todos que demonstram o desespero de um mundo que chegou ao seu fim. Não existe, no entanto, um clima pesado. Pelo contrário, toda a narrativa é contada com muito humor. 

(...)

------------------------------------------------------------------

http://falange.net/falange-resenha-the-end-is-nigh/

33712742.review:
As a huge fan of both Super Meat Boy as well as most of McMillan's games, this is an amazing game in my opinion, but I will add a warning to this review. If you do not like challenging games, don't get The End is Nigh, even if you do maybe watch a couple videos and see what you think. In my case, I bought it almost as soon as it came out without even remembering the game was being released. A freind and I played it for about four hours straight that night taking turns and trying our best to figure out the mechanics, and I have to say in my case I felt it was totally worth the price point, yes its challenging but if you push through the frustration and stress it can be very rewarding depending on who you are.

I will emphicize again that this game is not for those who want something easy, but then again most of Edmund's games don't necissarily fit the description of 'easy'. If you loved Super Meat Boy like I did when it came out, you will most likely enjoy this game, its not too similar to feel like a sequel but instead has its own ideas of challenging the player in a way that makes them want to do everything better. Everything from the mechanics to the soundtrack made me feel motivated to become better at the game's mechanics and intracacies, as simple as they may be.

For $15 I was expecting something I could master in 10 hours or so, but instead I got a game that I feel like I could play for a hundred hours and still feel like I could improve on certain things, and to me that makes this game one of the best platformers I've played in a very long time.

On a side note, I find this game much easier to play with a controller, I played through almost half of it without but as soon as I tried playing with a gamepad I can't even imagine playing it with a keyboard. That might just be me though, I know a lot of people prefer keyboard for games like this but I'm not one of them, jumping at specific angles is just much easier for me with a joystick.

33712512.review:
A diabolically difficult platformer with tight controls, The End is Nigh is a worthy spiritual successor to Super Meat Boy. Not as fast paced as Super Meat Boy , The End is Nigh features multiple collectibles including cartridges that unlock minigames and tumors, which are often in hard to reach spots adding a layer of difficulty to already difficult levels.  Exploration is an important component to The End is Nigh, and the gameplay is so satisfying as to make it feel worthwhile. 

The music starts to get tiresome after a while – they definitely needed more tracks. What is there is great, though.
Pick this up if you want a tight platformer – you’ll easily spend hours just playing through the levels before you start to look for secrets.

Definitely recommended.

33710144.review:
[u] I haven't put a tonne of hours into this yet- so this review is just after 691 deaths, to be exact. [/u]


I played a LOT of Super Meat Boy (even if my Steam hours don't show that) and I absolutely [b] love [/b] platformer games!

SMB was probably the game that got me really into them, whereas sure I'd gotten experience in a lot of the games from my childhood, Super Meat Boy really tested my skills and it showed my fingers & tendons what a game could ask of them!

This game though.... [i] damn. [/i]
Controls feels tremendously tight, even more so than Super Meat Boy and any of the other few platformers I know of with tight & responsive controls. The music- as always in Edmund's games, is brilliant. But what really gets me is how amazingly the levels I've come across so far are designed!

So as most other reviews have probably mentioned (and if not the one YouTube video I watched before buying this mentioned it) - This game has no loading screens between levels. All the levels you come across you can walk in and out of with ease. Now while this may not seem like a huge deal on it's own... With level design like this game has (which I assure you is bloody fantastic, just likely designed by the devil himself) it means there's an incredible amount of secrets that take advantage of this mechanic, and the game overall just feels a whole lot more connected within itself. With SMB you are taken out of the level when you finish it and you're plonked on the next level in the map select screen, and whilst I've nothing against that; after playing The End Is Nigh for a little over an hour and a half it's obvious to me how much I prefer it personally.

[u] Quick recap / TL;DR: [/u]
[list]
[*]Amazingly responsive and tight controls (oh and I forgot to mention the spikes' hitboxes too, they're spot-on)
[*]Great soundtrack.
[*]No in & out gameplay with lots of loading screens.
[*]Tough as NAILS platforming- there are some [b] EVIL [/b] level designs (especially to get collectables)
[*]A [i] lot [/i] of secrets. Trust me. Also there's over 30 hidden achievements..
[*]Lovely graphics style, if you liked Super Meat Boy / The Binding of Isaac / The Basement Collection for their style it's the same guy, you're in luck :)
[/list]

So hey, overall my first impressions of this have been fantastic. And having a quick peak at the achievements has made me eager to try to catch them all.. But something tells me it's going to be a long and painful journey... 

...But still fun! I swear! I enjoy it.. ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)



Hope this review helped somehow, might update it at some point in the future when I've more hours put in.
Thanks for reading.

33707102.review:
I'm sad to say that it's a slower, duller, lazier and uglier version of Super Meat Boy. It's not horrible, it's just not as good.

First, the game just looks flat. McMillen's games always looked a bit simplistic but Super Meat Boy definitely had a wow-effect. The End is Nigh doesn't. It's just a monotonous gray&black palette and not a single spark of fun in the image. Remember how expressive and fun SMB or The Binding of Isaac look; that's what you won't find here.

It controls similarly to SMB but it's slower, and while SMB had an extremely fun core mechanic of sliding meat-physics, TEIN offers you... well, hanging on ledges. It even sounds boring. In addition to that there's also water, and water controls just feel clunky and off-putting.

In addition to that the game is just easy unless you're collecting tumors. Tumors are collectables, but not like patches in SMB, which were rare and exceedingly hard to get. Here tumors are on every screen (and every screen is basically a level) and unless you decide to get them you miss the whole point of the game. So basically instead of being a really hard game it forces you to go for additional objective so that you make it a hard game.

And worst of all, TEIN commits a sin of being monotonous. Where in SMB each level was a sort of a chess party at a million miles per hour, TEIN feels like you're just moving from a small puzzle to a small puzzle. And it many ways it is true because each level is now 1 screen, and most of them are the same size.

The only great thing about it is music. But it's not enough for me to not refund it. Sorry, Edmund, I'd rather go torture Isaac some more.

33690932.review:
Having been a fan of previous McMillen games, I picked up The End is Nigh when it was first announcened. Now that I've beaten the game, I'm a touch torn on my feelings towards the game. Some of the design decisions work for me; others not so much. 

What I liked:

+ The McMillen Astethic + Design
+ Environments/Worlds
+ Ash
+ The Past 
+ Sound Design + Soundtrack
+ Value

What I didn't like:

- Controls are janky at times on controller (Ash seems to miss ledge grabs way more then with keyboard).
- Collectibles: I'm all for collectibles in games, but make them feel rewarding. Some of the carts in The Future are just a pain to get and all they unlock are harder platforming levels (having the major draw be achievements is just a waste imo; Isaac showers players with fun unlocks & Achievements)
- Levels: While I understand this is a precision platformer, some of the levels just get downright monotonous at times. 
- Ash: Ash is seriously underutilized as a character. More Ash!
- The Future: Didn't really work for me. Felt kind of off. 

Overall I enjoyed my time with The End is Nigh, but I'm not really itching to jump back into it. There are a few design decisions that didn't really work all that well for me. With that being said, I'm sure if you love platformers, this game will be really fun to you. 

7/10

33686443.review:
The End is Nigh is an arcade-y platformer that feels similar to Super Meat Boy (since Edmund McMillen partly designed both); but the main mechanic involves hanging from ledges/hooks to long jump, rather than being able to wall-jump anywhere. It can still can be played very quickly, and often the fastest path is the most efficient way to progress. 

Each world consists of 20 or so screens that serve as individual challenges (with many secrets), and if you die you will instantly respawn wherever you came in from. The difficulty curve is well paced, but this game gets very difficult in its second act, so it may not be for everyone. I'm currently at 98% and I'll probably leave it at that, however there are many hidden challenges/achievements that I can still attempt to do, if I feel up to the intense trials. 

The soundtrack was created by Ridiculon (who composed the OST to BOI: Rebirth), and it consists of short remixes of classical pieces that range from "Flight of the Bumblebee", "In the Hall of the Mountain King" and "Night on Bald Mountain". The soundtrack's repetition in each area will either drive you mad as you fail to make that one jump, or you may find yourself in tune with the game itself, pushing yourself forward just to hear the next song. I was in the latter camp, and I never found the music annoying enough to turn off, even after my hours of failed attempts in the later worlds.

Overall I really enjoyed my time with it; it never felt unfair and I never felt too frustrated outside of the cartridges, but I'm probably more patient/skilled than the average player. I may come back and try to beat the 4 cartridges I have left, but I'm satisfied with it at this point. My commendations to Tyler Glaiel and Edmund McMillen; the game feels great, it is fun and accessible, and still presents enough of a challenge for hardcore players who really want test their skills.

33674965.review:
While I do recommend this game, it certainly has its share of pros and cons.  It's absolutely a blast to play, and it controls fantastically.  The only people I've heard complain about controls are people who play with the joystick ... don't do that ... it's a 2D platformers, use the d-pad ... that's what it's there for!

The music is a lot of fun, and the visuals are engaging, ranging from cutesy-macabre to hauntingly beautiful.  The levels are all deliberately made and offer appropriate challenge, and rewarding feelings for completing them.  And there are a LOT of them.  

I think were the game falls flat is first, and least importantly, the writing.  The little blurbs the NPC's say are trite and cringingly "edgey" as if it's a collection of the worst quotes from a 15 year old on /r/atheism.  But I can get over that, since we all know Edmund has a hard-on for hating on/mocking Christianity.  But I think this goes hand-in-hand with my biggest complaint ... the game feels like it's got no heart.  At least in games like Super Meat Boy or 1001 Spikes it felt like there was a heart, or a certain joyfullness to them.  The End is Nigh is fun to play and I plan to chip away at it for as long as it takes to complete, but I don't look back on it with joy, and I don't anticipate playing it later the same way I do Super Meat Boy.  Games like Super Meat Boy and 1001 Spikes would always be in the back of my mind at work or whatever, when I was in the middle of them, but not so much The End is Nigh.  It just feels like a time-filler, kind of like a mobile game, in that I'll pick it up and play for an hour, then maybe forget about it for a few days and do it again.  

Despite that it's a solid game, and definitely one for any platforming-junky.  I truly do like it, I just think it's missing a little something to send it over the edge and into greatness.  But don't take my word for it ... go and play it yourself!

[h1]El hermano de Super Meat Boy y el Primo de Isaac[/h1]
Voy a intentar ser breve. Me encanta The End is Nigh.
 Es dificil. 
Te hace casi llegar al limite de querer dejar el juego con rabia, cagandote en todo. Lo roza... pero no llegas nunca. De esa manera, cuando te das  cuenta, llevas horas jugando y te sientes un ninja. 

De que va el juego? Facil
El mundo ha terminado. Todo ha muerto. Y nosotros... casi.
Pero no estamos muertos del todo y nos sentimos solos. 
Vamos a intentar conseguir un amigo para que nos haga compañia. Todos han muerto asi que nos lo construiremos nosotros... a base de trozos :D
Recorreremos el mundo destruido y ya de paso coleccionaremos tumores. Si si, tumores. Si tenemos suerte y conseguimos los necesarios, podremos acceder a zonas en las que con suerte, nos llevaremos de regalo un cartucho para nuestra consola de videojuegos. De esa forma tendremos distracción para rato.

Los niveles son chungos, los cartuchos contienen mini-juegos completos (con sus mini logros y todo) y todo acompañado de una banda sonora BUENÍSIMA. Identificaremos algun tema de TboI remezclado y algún que otro clasico adaptado al entorno del juego.

La paleta de colores me parece buenísima también.

En resumen, un dinero que creo que amortizaremos muy rápido con esta pequeña obra maestra. Clásico instáneo.

33654883.review:
The End Is Nigh è la sardonica allegoria di un viaggio che, attraverso rievocazioni storiche e religiose, riesce contemporaneamente a carpire e sbalordire il giocatore. Come una matriosca, al suo interno si annidano molteplici significati e allusioni che restituiscono all’ultima opera di Edmund McMillen e Tyler Glaiel uno spirito indubitabilmente moderno. Dai complessi industriali che esalano nubi tossiche fino ad arrivare alle spettrali rovine di un futuro pieno di sofferenza e dolore, The End Is Nigh comunica un profondo messaggio di critica sociale. Come se non bastasse il piccolo indie fa suo un gusto retro tipico delle melodie chiptune, mentre recupera il canone ludico di Super Meat Boy, espandendolo grazie ad una struttura che supera quella “a stage” del suo ideale predecessore, per farsi mondo continuo e interconnesso (alla Metroidvania). Se avete amato la poliedricità dei lavori di McMillen, non potete assolutamente perdervi questo titolo.

Trovate la recensione completa su Everyeye.it: http://www.everyeye.it/articoli/recensione-the-end-is-nigh-del-nuovo-gioco-edmund-mcmillen-34259.html

33652390.review:
Clunky controls (sticking to walls sometimes works and sometimes it doesn't - especially with moving platforms), platforming gameplay consisting of dodging crap flying at you from all sides or jumping on the crumbling/sinking structures (which is just annoying), acceptable graphics and music - all of that creates a game that... I don't want to play anymore :P It feels like underdeveloped Super Meat Boy (one of the best platformers ever imo)

Bottom line - this game cured me from preordering games. I trusted Edmund McMillen, he served me rushed, underdeveloped junk. I don't recommend TEIN

EDIT: and I really wanted this to be the next SMB with insane challenges to complete, fluent gameplay and tons of joy. But this game is just not fun (at least for me). Simple as that.

Let's get the topics I have less to say about out of the way first.

Controls:
The controls are precise, simple and feel good. In all of my time with the game I have never felt like the controls were the cause of any of my (over 8000) deaths. I have been using keyboard.

Music and sound effects:
The soundtrack is a host of remade classical pieces and as expected of Ridiculon, it is great. The sounds are also mostly very good, though some seem a bit too loud and others get annoying after a while.

Visuals:
Looks pretty good for a 2D platformer.

Story:
The story is obviously not the focus of the game. It's rather simple but it's not boring.

Gameplay:
Now for the big one.
The game is not easy. At times it is brutally difficult. However, the game is still a lot of fun and most of the time, the difficulty is fair. The main levels are generally not too frustrating. There are many little collectibles and secrets, a great amount of achievements and the number of levels the game has to offer is amazing. Beating hard challenges is satisfying and there are some optional insanely difficult ones for the hardcore players.

The game does have some flaws though:
1. It makes you replay levels multiple times if you want to collect all the collectibles. Some people may dislike this. (I personally have no problem with it)
2. A few levels contain obstacles that are unpredictable and unfair. This issue is only present in maybe about 1% of all levels though and it mostly doesn't have a high chance of killing you. But it sucks when it does.
3. If you are bad at platformers or have a short temper, this game could be incredibly frustrating for you.

Bonus:
The End is Nigh is very easily moddable and there are already a bunch of cool mods that add extra levels (check out the official discord if you wanna play them). This gives the game quite a bit more longevity. I am modding it myself and I never expected to put so many hours into a singleplayer platformer.

All in all, the game is great and I wholeheartedly recommend it.

As someone who did 106% and almost all achievements in Super Meat Boy, I can understand some of the negative feedback the game is getting. The End is Nigh is nowhere near Super Meat Boy in terms of quality. It's not as challenging and certainly not as fun.

The ledge-grabbing mechanic - unlike SMB's wall sliding -  is incredibly unreliable and kind of ruins the game for me. This is the only reason people feel this game is hard. Why can't you warp to a particular level once you completed a world? Why can you only warp to worlds? It makes no sense. It's just bland and ininspired platforming. Ed should go back to the drawing board. Sorry for the pun, but this game has no "meat" in it.

33635937.review:
[b]Персональный рейтинг - 6,5 из 10[/b]

[i]МакМиллен-фактор, или В космосе никто не услышит твой мат[/i]

Играя в The End is Nigh, все же понимаешь, что платформеры - самый бесчеловечный жанр, который придумали мизантропы. Это как клоуны-убийцы, которые вроде с красным носом и идиотских ботинках не по размеру, а на деле маньяки и садисты.

От Super Meat Boy игра взяла основу игрового процесса - жесткий платформинг для сильных духом и нервами, с крепким пожаростойким седалищем, позволяющим выдерживать нагрузки самой разной степени. На каждом из многочисленных этапов есть Опухоль - коллекционный предмет, который сослужит вам службу на поздних стадиях игры. Можно даже находить картриджи с 8-битными играми, в которые можно поиграть и получить награду в виде тех же Опухолей и достижений.

Впрочем, первые уровни и миры игры проходятся относительно легко. Кажется даже, что автор сдал и специально в угоду современной моде решил упростить свое творение. Однако чем дальше идет дело - тем больше понимаешь, что старый конь МакМиллен еще не попортил борозды. Когда происходящее минует экватор, автор переключает рубильник и начинаются настоящие испытания, требующие отточенной реакции, виртуозного обращения с кнопкой прыжка и точных таймингов. Если отправитесь в секретную область и возжелаете наложить руки на таящиеся там бонусы вроде Мега-Опухолей или картриджей с новыми играми, то тут сложность будет совсем бешеной, и на прохождение таких этапов у вас может уйти огромное число попыток. 

На последних этапах автор слетает с катушек и выкатывает все, что у него есть. Тут и успеть в последнюю долю секунды, прыгнуть с нужного пикселя, успеть за отведенное время, успеть за ограниченное количество жизней, будут все круги платформенного ада. Невольно представляешь себе сидящего с секундомером и логарифмической линейкой автора, замеряющего расстояния прыжков, просчитывающего дистанции и сдвигающего на дополнительный миллиметр край уступа или обрыва, висящего над озером лавы. Потому что хардкор и все такое.

Тем не менее поиск Опухолей со временем превращается в рутину. Оказавшись на новом этапе, первым делом ищешь Опухоль и думаешь, как ее достать. Это кажется интересным на словах, и действительно первые 20 уровней это развлекает, но, когда это повторяется в 100-й раз, хочется плюнуть на эти висящие в воздухе комочки черной слизи и просто допрыгать до выхода, не паря мозг.

К слову о прыжках и управлении в целом - оно не слишком удачное. Механика прыжков хоть и попроще, чем в SMB (в отличие от Мит Боя главный герой Эш не может ускоряться при беге), но на практике работает кривовато. Суть проста, чем дольше жмешь на кнопку - тем выше прыгает герой. Коварство в том, что для выполнения отдельных прыжков нужно не просто плавно нажать, нужно практически подуть на кнопку - таким "нежным" должно быть нажатие. Понять, что ты нажал правильно, почти невозможно. Из-за этого недолетаешь, перелетаешь или бьешься головой о шипы на потолке практически регулярно.

Довольно полезным умением является захватиться за выступ обрыва или пропасти, повиснув на краю, но в обучении эта тактика объяснена весьма расплывчато. На деле следует удерживать кнопку "Пригнуться" и просто подъехать к краю, герой сам ухватится за выступ.

Сложность некоторых этапов обставлена довольно бесхитростно - вместо одного прыгающего врага на вас вываливают пять, плюс одного бегающего, одного ползующего и еще кого-нибудь впридачу, чтобы веселее проходилось. И поскольку у нас тут хардкор и все дела, то можно еще пару бездонных ям и острых шипов добавить для острастки.

Все это приправлено щепоткой макмилленовской псевдофилософии про что-то там. Что это - непонятно никому, возможно даже самому МакМиллену, но это что-то - определенно очень темное и мрачное. Какой же ты в конце концов хипстер и икона жанра без глубокомысленных метафор и скрытых смыслов?

В музыкальном плане дуэт композиторов не слишком напрягался. Все треки - обработка классических мелодий Брамса, Грига, Листа и прочих. 

Удел подобных игр - проверить вас на прочность. Дать вам возможность потешить свое эго, пройдя тяжелый этап. Затем попробовать следующий, погибнуть тысячу раз, прожечь под собой стул, плюнуть, пойти пить чай, попробовать еще раз, наконец пройти, обрадоваться, попробовать совсем сложный уровень, погибнуть две тысячи раз, прожечь второй стул и еще ковер под ним, грязно выругаться, удалить, потом отправиться смотреть на потуги спидраннеров с канала AGDQ, благо игра прекрасно заточена под скоростное прохождение.

33634101.review:
Amazing game. Extremely hard, and extremely challenging, but extremely fun. I actually don't get angry at all while playing this game, because each time I die I just see room for me to do it again. While I'm around 3.5k deaths already and am still early on the game, gotta say, it's a blast to play and a shit ton of fun.

Looking for secrets is also very amusing, some of them are extremely well hidden, requiring you to backtrack in order to find the entrance to them.

The game pretty much forces you to die a bunch of times to learn and improve quickly, as each level is relatively small and easy to master (aside from a few special levels, which take a little more patience and skill to do). In other words: Stop Raging and Git Gud, the game.

As for how this game stands along other Edmund games, I'd say it's pretty equal. If you compare it to SMB, the game is almost a polar opposite of sorts, being more calculated, precise and time-taking, rather than a level where speed and skill is what matters most.

There are some really unfair levels for more unskilled players though. On a certain level, I probably died at least 1000 times in 2 screens. Granted I'm not amazing at platformers, it took me a while to be able to be able to do a small portion of it consistently, and a good while to finish said level.

Regarding controls, I wish they were a little better for Mouse and Keyboard users. The game is very unforgiving to M&K, for the fact that it's hard to control your speed, since if you don't have a mechanical Keyboard you can't slightly tilt the key, and jumping turns into a bit of a nightmare, since this game has that one mechanic where the longer you hold the jump button, the farther you jump, which isn't necessarily easy to gauge when you're playing on a keyboard and pressing the jump key a lot. TL;DR, the game kind of has a big favoritism for controllers.

The soundtrack is also very fitting for the game. It just gives just the correct platformer vibe, taking the setting of the game in consideration.

I definetely recommend this game, 100%. If you like Edmund's other game and challenge, this game is for you, my friend.

El juego me lo voy a pasar... dudo que al 100% pero ya tengo una opinion formada:


-El control es perfecto y sencillo, muy satisfactorio.

-La bso me parece una maravilla, interpretaciones de piezas clásicas, le dan un toque sereno, sobrio, triste y emocionante.

-Es verdad que como han mencionado muchas veces tiene algo que recuerda al donkey kong. Algo que me parece muy característico de esa saga, es que tiene un ritmo de juego característico, saltando de enemigo en enemigo, de barril en barril, se encadenan movimientos durante secuencias relativamente largas. Aquí ocurre eso. Puedes tirarte ciegamente a la acción y por instinto, pasártela. Obviamente hay muchos secretos que requieren atención, pero el juego estimula ese arrojo.

-El apartado artístico también me parece elegante e impecable.

-El diseño de niveles me parece perfecto, es muy interesante analizar cómo afrontar cada uno, o ir entendiendo cómo funciona a base de muertes. Algunos parecen ecosistemas propios, con idas y venidas, pero al estar todos interconectados en un gran mapa da sensación de mundo en si mismo. Me parece un diseño más inteligente y efectivo que los niveles de super meat boy.

Es el juego más difícil que me he encontrado. Pero se aprende solo, la curva de dificultad es empinada y rápida pero se nota cómo te adaptas. Se consigue lo "imposible" y da gustito. Pero también se pasa mal.

33623741.review:
普通模式（THE PAST）通关，来表达一下感受。

历时13小时，总收集77%，死亡4650。

TEIN的画风延续了以撒的“惨萌”风格，小煤球很可爱，怪物很可（残）爱（暴），收集的TUMOR很可爱，让玩家仿佛置身于一个可爱的世界里自由冒险。（并不）

平台跳跃类游戏多以难度高的形象示人，TEIN也不例外。
TEIN在难度曲线上控制的比较合理，难度随关卡深入层层递进，TUMOR的存在也使得收集并通关和单纯的破关两者存在明显的难度差别，不热衷于此的玩家则可以直接沿着更清晰明白的大路通关，喜欢挑战的玩家，可以走更加危险和隐蔽的道路去收集TUMOR，每次过关后都可以+1、+1、+1，享受生命不断涌来的快感。
而后期关卡的各种新机制新敌人新陷阱，使得关卡平均难度骤然升高。（尤指收集部分，如TUMOR和隐藏）可以说是提供了相当多具有挑战性的部分，可玩性十足。

值得一提的是TEIN在控制角色上设置为根据按键时间可轻重跳，这一方面使得玩家的操作显得尤为关键，同时更要观察如何利用地形、机关去规避轻重跳带来的不确定性；另一方面，本作确实设置了不少的要求玩家用操作硬过的关卡（主要设置在隐藏关），因此诸如笔者这样的轻度手残玩家玩起来偶有闹心之感。

TEIN的质量是完全对得起这个价格的，E胖对平台跳跃游戏的把控力很强，尤其是丰富的激励措施十分值得学习借鉴。

喜欢蹦跶的朋友不要犹豫了，早买早享受。

附：13小时完成的仅仅是THE PAST，之后还有ANGUISH（困难模式），该模式下似乎没有收集要素，关卡难度提升不少，游戏流程事实上还是比较长的，算的上耐玩，但还是建议适度游戏，保护您的身心健康和键盘。

The End is Nigh trashes the wall jumps and speed ups in favor of a more percision based platformer. 

The art style is simplistic but does its job in capturing an end of world sort of feeling. Ash's design is simple, but goes with the overall effect the game's style tries to make. 

The music is outstanding and Edmund has done it again with extremely well done soundtracks. 

My main issue with the game is that there are instances where you essentially are forced to die to learn what something dies, and levels are not doable at first glance. You have to learn what something does through trial and error but you should be able to eyeball it rather then take 10 deaths to realize the spring falls and you have to catch up with it in time. 

overall, I love what i've played, and the difficulty is very high but still possible. 
It's a 7.5/10 for me, right now. 
I'll update when i have finished the game!

33621608.review:
This game has its cake and eats it too by structuring itself to allow the player to choose which content to tackle, as the game can vary from mildly difficult all the way up to extremely challenging. The game also manages to serve as an adventure platforming, hiding a number of secrets in the game in the form of clever level design, at the expense of removing the wall jump and sprint mechanics which restricts player movement enough to allow for this sort of level design. Also theres no sprint button so you can actually play it with a keyboard which if you're like me was a huge dealbreaker in SMB.

Overall this game is very good, easily my second favourite edmund game behind boi and ahead of smb. To go into what I like about it would take too long for a review so few people will probably read, but if you like either puzzle platformers or precision platformers this game is definitely for you. It also has phenomenal visual design and a killer soundtrack. I honestly cant think of any real criticisms I have aside from a few of the enemies being poorly designed mechanically (looking at you skullbirds) luckily the devs must have noticed this and restricted them each to a single area. Overall this game is a solid 9.5/10 for me, and I dont even usually like platformers that much!

33619465.review: They have done it again. Some of the minds behind Super Meat Boy have created yet another amazing platformer. Super Meat Boy was, and still is, one of my favorite games of all time, and already I can say that The End is Nigh is rising up to that point. It has smooth, tight controls and all sorts of new challenges. One of my favorite things about Super Meat Boy was the insane challenge that some levels presented, but then also the incredible feeling of beating those levels. The End is Nigh delivers on this as well, as the controls and gameplay are so well formed, yet simple, that you really feel accomplished when you beat a level. It's that classic "hard, but fair" type of game where the levels may be crazy, but the tight controls can't be to blame for the difficulty. I highly recommend this game for anyone who loved Meat Boy and anyone who loves platformers and incredible challenge.

33608394.review:
As a Super Meat Boy veteran, I find The End is Nigh really, really nice.

The platforming itself is top notch, because of the high quality level design and tight controls. This time around, there's a lot of exploration, and the difficulty has been ramped up considerably.

The visual side is well done too. Each area has its distinctive colour palette and style. You gather game cartridges, which can be played in the player character's home - these are reminiscent of the warp levels in Super Meat Boy. That is to say, they're retro platformers with big pixels, with chiptune accompaniment. Also, they get really challenging. (Especially when you find so-called iron cartridges - but I'll shut up about those.)

I think I'm about halfway done with the game, according to the in-game completion percentage, with 13 hours played at the time of writing. I don't think I'll ever get 100% completion because of the insane difficulty, but even finding most of the stuff and getting a "normal ending" (if there's such a thing), will provide hours and hours of more gameplay.

Highly recommended if you like challenging platforming with short levels and lots of repetition to get it right, with high production values.

Мы играем за странное существо, которое пережило апокалипсис и потеряло всё - от своего глаза до последней работающей видеоигры. Теперь нам предстоит посреди всего этого апокалипсиса собрать себе друга...по частям.
Игра, ожидаемо, сложная. Но перепроходить уровни не надоедает, твоя очередная смерть лишь раззадоривает тебя. Также по уровням разбросаны ништяки. Если не пытаться их собрать, уровень можно пройти даже более или менее безболезненно...но мы ведь не ищем лёгких путей, да?

However it does become tedious when you have to clear through an entire stage multiple times over with no warp points inbetween for all the collectibles. There are also no really big mechanics that make the game itself. Where SMB was a platformer that shot-for-the-middle, had tight controls and interesting levels, making just an all-round good platformer, The End is Nigh never really shows anything too mechanically innovative (other than the appliances of the ledge-jump), which makes it very much the same as SMB. However, as a fan of Edmund's previous work, I still throughly enjoyed a taste of something new, giving me another game to challenge myself with. It doesn't feature any aspect that is glaringly bad, and for those looking for this type of game (like myself), The End is Nigh is likely to satisfy.

I find this surprising, but I like this more than super meat boy. It has a better (as in more) plot, More interesing level design, and more interesting collectibles. Don't be fooled, however, as this is just as cat-rapingly hard as Edmund's other works.

The world is, rather than level based, a complete world. You can play through multiple "worlds" in a row without ever opening a menu. There are some portions which are one-way, which is annoying, but its generally free-roam. The fast travel system is helpful as well.

In each level there is a tumor to collect, and these unlock more levels. There are also hidden game cartridges, which are even more levels. Each of these also have their own achievements.

The controls are extremely good. Near all of my deaths felt like they were my fault. Theyare also very simplistic, with only movement, jumping, and a hastened-falling move (You'll see what I mean). The soundtrack is also kick-ass.

Overall, buy this game. Its just more proof for my case that Edmund McMillan is the best indie dev.

33597075.review:
Se você está lendo isso, você provavelmente tem 3 dúvidas sobre esse jogo: se ele é um "Super Meat Boy 2" mesmo, se ele é difícil, e se ele é bom. Então vamos lá.

[h1]É parecido com Super Meat Boy?[/h1]

Sim, mas não é exatamente uma continuação. Acho que a comparação mais justa seria como a diferença entre [i]Dark Souls[/i] e [i]Bloodborne[/i]. Enquanto [b]Super Meat Boy[/b] tem um gameplay bem rápido, muito baseado em reflexo e em controle total do personagem, [b]The End Is Nigh[/b] tira um pouco dessa velocidade e traz um gameplay um pouco mais estratégico. 

Você não tem tem [i]walljump[/i] nem corrida, ao invés disso o personagem consegue se agarrar nas beiradas das plataformas e em "ganchos" específicos. O ritmo acaba sendo um pouco mais lento, com menos improviso e exigindo mais precisão e planejamento.

Além disso, cada "mundo" funciona como uma coisa só, sendo as fases apenas transições de telas, tudo interligado, incluindo até um pouco de [i]backtracking[/i]. E pra finalizar, aqui você tem ainda mais segredos (passagens secretas nas fases) e coletáveis, que também acabam sendo mais importantes mais pra frente do jogo, e não só pura satisfação pessoal.

[h1]O jogo é difícil mesmo?[/h1]

Meu amigo, é sim. Muito. Meu Deus, e como é. Eu tenho o costume de gostar de jogos considerados difíceis e estressantes, mas esse aqui leva isso pra um novo nível.

O estilo de gameplay já deixa ele um pouco mais difícil do que SMB (pois é, eles conseguiram), mas como só isso não seria o bastante,  o jogo tem várias partes criadas com o mais puro sadismo materializado. Eu nunca tinha xingado tanto um jogo antes como fiz com esse. Me desculpe mãe do Edmund, eu sei que a senhora não tem nada a ver com isso, foi apenas stress do momento, ok?

Mas tenha em mente que BOA parte do desafio vem de "conteúdo extra", então se você quiser apenas terminar o jogo vai ser uma experiência bem balanceada.

[h1]Mas o jogo é bom?[/h1]

Eu até queria que fosse ruim, pra poder deixar de lado sem peso na consciência, mas infelizmente o jogo é muito bom. Gameplay preciso, level design muito bem montado, visual e trilha sonora super charmosos e conteúdo pra jogar por muito tempo.

Eu ainda nem fiz 100% do jogo e já sinto que minha expectativa de vida diminuiu em pelo menos 9 anos, mas não me arrependo.

33594941.review:
I bought this game since I am a huge fan of McMillen's previous games. I spent a lot of time playing and completing everything in Super Meat Boy, so when I heard about a new platformer I got really excited, and I think a lot of people will be in the same situation.

It's important to understand that while they both are hardcore platformers, they are quite different. The End is Nigh is set in a semi-open world and each "level" is connected with another, compared to the "world-by-world" setup of Super Meat Boy. Sometimes you'll have to go back to another level to access a secret or another path, which make it really interesting.   

Also interesting that there isn't any bosses, which to me was both a pro and con. Meat Boy had some great bosses ideas, but most of them could be rendered trivial due to the limited options related to being a two-button platformer, so not having those kind of fights between worlds felt like a good idea to keep the rythme of the game.

The level-design is rich, and you never really get to grow tired of a specific mechanic as new ones are introduced regularly. Since you don't get any "upgrade", the level-design will dictate your possibilities, and I feel like you get a linear progression that is extremely rewarding.

Lots of different worlds will help with the basic story-telling of the game, but don't expect too much bare a couple cinematics and some hidden text. It's a gameplay-first kind of game. 
Talking about that, it's pleasing graphically and the animations are really fluid, which should be no surprise to those who played Super Meat Boy. They know how to make a platformer feel great.

I personally finished the main-levels but still have a lot to discover, which again is kind of the trademark of McMillen's games. 
All in all, get this game if you want a challenging but rewarding experience that feels good to play, and have the patience to accept thousands of deaths. It's a steal for this price and one of the best platformer I ever played.
