33590477.review:
This is the most incredible 2d platformer I've ever played. 

Too many people getting upset and leaving negative reviews because they lack the patience and skill it takes to conquer a challenging platformer just tells me you're not good enough.

This is not Super Meat Boy, so don't bother calling it "Super Meat Boy 2". This game's leaps and bounds ahead of SMB, and I loved Meat Boy.

The fact that you run at a consistent speed is a positive and the fact that you cannot wall jump lets the levels be as creative with ledges and mechanics as possible.

This game is much more technical, mechanical, and pure as a platformer than Super Meat Boy which is simply a bad game compared to The End Is Nigh.

Pros
- Simple yet complex, this game has fall control, ledge manipulation, multiple jump heights and 2+ ways to jump off ledges.
- Certain levels like 'SS Exodus' feature objects with physics that are super fun to play around.
- Secrets and collectibles that are way more satisfying and challenging than collecting stale bandages.
- Non-linear open-world platforming which is far less boring than the stage-by-stage snoozefest that was Meat Boy.
- Challenging learning curve and challenging "retro" levels that require practicing and learning to gain mastery of the level.
- NPC's scattered around levels with interesting dialogue, behind a challenging way to reach some of them, of course.
- Some of the most clever and challenging level design in a 2d game.
- Many different enemy types to challenge you with their own strengths and weaknesses to learn and conquer.
- Tyler Glaiel is the best programmer yet. Day one, this man was fixing bugs and patching the game, there's been almost 10 updates and this game has been out only for 4 days.
- Edmund McMillen games are always extremely creative and interesting, lore-wise.
- Best music in any Edmund McMillen game.

Cons
- None I can think of at the moment...yeah, none.

Get The End Is Nigh. It's worth it.

Super Meat Boyを制作した人が関わっていて、そちらを好きだった人はこちらも楽しめると思います。
プレイ時間は本編をクリアで10時間ほどで、ミニゲームはまだ手をつけてません（本編よりも高難易度です）。
１つのステージは１つの画面（固定）で構成されていて、次のステージに進む道と、１つのソウルがあります（稀に隠し道もあります）。
ソウルというのはこれを一定数集めればミニゲームをアンロックすることが出来ます。
それと、（ネタバレ）[spoiler]表面で集めたソウル数が裏面の残機となります。残機を使い果たすとエリア毎（２０ステージ程）の最初からになります。	[/spoiler]

コントローラーを思わず投げたくなるほど（褒め言葉）の高難易度ゲームですが、
上手く行った時やギミックを解いた時や隠し道を見つけた時の喜びは素晴らしいものがあります。
俗に言う死にゲーに耐性があり、2Dプラットフォーマーアクションが好きなら遊んで楽しんでください。

33578623.review:
Do you like getting navigating your way through a level full of spikes at high speed with slippery controls, dying at the very end, and repeating it fifty times? If so, I have good news: this game has all that, plus you can't skip to specific levels, so if you're tired of one area halfway through it, you can either fuck yourself or die another 300 times getting back through levels you've already beaten! And there's levels that start you in midair above the entrance, so you fall back into the previous level unless you remember every single time that you have to move left as soon as you spawn!

You'd think they couldn't fit any more into a small indie game, but you'd be wrong, because there's also a ton of secrets scattered throughout, and you'd better get every single one as you go, or it's yet another round of backtracking and dying hundreds of times on levels you've already completed. What great value.

Первое, что стоит заметить - инноваций в игре почти ноль что, в общем-то, не мешает ей быть достойным младшим братом SMB.

Сразу из минусов:
Ранило в сердешко отсутствие боссов и секретных персонажей.
Монетизация ремиксов произведений классики, серьезно?
Невозможность выбирать необходимый тебе "уровень", что заставляет тебя проходить каждый раз главу сначала.
Хоть это и происходит всего 2-3 раза за игру, но попытки придать этому сгустку опухоли в кат-сценах образ "плохого" парня методом ругани - выглядят довольно кринжово.
Местами игра действительно кажется не проходимой (можете и должны сослаться на мою рукожёпость)

Но, тем не мение:
Левелдизайн и саундтрек у игры шикарны (от локации пещер аж мурашки пошли), пасхалки в виде милейших приведений доставляют, а управление персонажем ощущается так же на уровне и интересно.

Снова сравнивая её с SMB стоит заметить, что хоть это и её младший брат, сама игра слегка другово жанра, представляя из себя не зaдрoчкy на прыжки по паттерну, а своего рода пазл, призывающий вас взаимодействовать с окружением:
Всё это - делает игру особенной, ни в коем случае не способной надоесть и запоминающейся (мой гейм-пад уж точно запомнит).

Farwell, comrades.

33566812.review:
Я считаю себя довольно большим поклонником творчества Эдмунда МакМиллена. Этот бородатый дядька в свое время перевернул и поднял значение инди игр в индустрии. Не смотря на то, что и раньше были игры вроде I wanna be the guy, именно после Super Meat Boy начался настоящий шквал хардкорных олдскульных платформеров. Уверен, что и до the Binding of Isaac было полно разных лайт рогаликов, но именно после выхода похождений голого плачущего мальчугана, этот жанр стал мега популярен. Потому от новой игры Эдмунда ждешь чего то нового. Этим "новым" должна была стать игра Mew-Genics про скрещивание котов во всяких монстров мяусенштейна (простите), но лично меня этот концепт вообще не возбуждал, потому игру и не ждал. Видимо и сам МакМиллен понял, что интересной игры у него из этого не получится и отменил проект. А вместо него выпустил The End is Nigh - очередной хардкорный платформер в духе Super Meat Boy. И в этом главная проблема игры.

Собственно, что из себя представляет игра. Есть герой, он может прыгать, может цепляться за уступы и отпрыгивать от них. С этим арсеналом нам предстоит пройти over 600 уровней которые напичканы всяческими ловушками. Вас будут сжирать враги, расстреливать, давить, топить, сжигать. На уровнях разбросанны особые коллекционные предметы - "опухоли". Если хотите попотеть чуть сильнее, можете попробовать их собирать. Нужны они для доступа в секретные уровни. По мимо сбора опухолей можно искать секретные локации в главах или, например, проходить дополнительные ОЧЕНЬ СУКА СЛОЖНЫЕ уровни в картриджах. Так в чем же проблема?

А проблема была описана в самом начале моей писанины. Инноваций - нет. Это просто очередной сложный платформер которых после выхода SMB навыходило тысяча. Если у TEiN что нибудь уникальное? Абсолютно ничего. Более того, по сравнению с SMB игра еще и стала проще, не в плане сложности прохождения, а в плане насыщенности контентом. Уровней много, но они занимают один экран и проходятся моментально. В игре нет боссов, нет секретных персонажей, нет каких то уникальных механик. Да, в одном уровне презентуют воду, но на этом все. В существовании этой игры вообще нет смысла. Зачем она была сделана? Что хотел сказать автор когда ее делал? Да ничего. Это просто бездушный комерческий продукт. Игра хорошая, но от Эдмунда МакМиллена ждешь большего. Ну хоть саундтрэк годный подвезли, спасибо Ridiculon за него.

P.S. Мне одному показалось, что хитбокс у шипов какой то огромный? EDMUND, PLS FIX

33565905.review: One of the best classic-style platformers, with no stupid puzzle elements and abilities, just movement keys, jump button and your patience. That's all that depends, because you will die a lot. Game offers a very nice and diversive level design - each of around 15 worlds have different traps, enemies and mechanics, like water, springs and gravity fields. On top of that, every collectibles fan will be very happy here, because you can find many secrets and bonus items on your way through the desolate world. However, it takes a lot of effort to collect all of them. The End is Nigh also has some flaws, like other games. For example, the different worlds consists mostly from 20 separate rooms/levels. If, by some chance, you left some collectible in the tenth level of this world, you can't just simply go to this level, collect it and then leave, because the warp points to each world are only at the beginning and the end, so collecting everything may become frustrating over the time. And one other thing I'd like to change, is make each world at least 10 levels longer, so all the traps and mechanics in the worlds, can be used in more ways and you can enjoy each of them a little bit longer, because most of them, are only one world exclusive. But I think this can be easily solved, by adding level editor and steam workshop in later updates. Overall great experience, good platformers like these are kinda rare these days, so if you are fan of this genre, don't wait for anything and buy this game. If not, 15€ might be a bit too much for you, but definitely buy it in any upcoming sale, cause the game is surely worth it.

33565846.review:
Edit: To be crystal clear to anyone who doesn't fully read the review with a critical eye - I don't like this game. While I am reviewing/considering Edmunds game dev history, [b]I am downvoting this game because I would not recommend it to friends[/b]. I tried a few times and I find it 'difficult for the sake of being difficult'. I think the levels are *simple* to get through, but brutally hard if you want to collect stuff. And the whole game is a collection game.

I will likely be deleting all further comments because they are becoming abusive and toxic. My review is fairly glowing for a negative review. There is no more discussion to be had. If you don't find it useful, simply downvote and move on.

---

[b][i]The End is Nigh[/i] is a good game, but does not continue the legacy of innovation that we have come to expect from Edmund.[/b] It's like your favorite band's worst album; if your neighbor created it, you would be impressed - but not when it comes from those that push genres forward.

Yes, I'm comparing apples and oranges, but at some point we have to. McMillen games are in a league of their own.

[b]Essentially, [i]The End is Nigh[/i] is a more 'puzzly' [i]Super Meat Boy[/i] set in a universe that reminds me of [i]World of Goo[/i].[/b] While some argue this title is different enough from [i]Super Meat Boy[/i], I feel they are missing the forest for the trees. What is important is that it is a 'hard-as-nails' platformer. Edmund already changed the platformer world with that mechanic. I don't really want him to revisit that same mechanic. I desperately want [i]innovation[/i] from Edmund - it's what he does best.

[b]Of course I mean this all in the most flattering way possible.[/b] [i]The End is Nigh[/i] does have many superb aspects. I'll get into that at the end of the review.

Edmund has historically made some really addicting and satisfying games. Creating a game with those traits is not easy, and is what a great majority of developers strive for. The formula has not been fully figured, and I think this is leading to some problems. Eddie knows that a game is very satisfying when you overcome something truly difficult - just play [i]Super Meat Boy[/i] to see what I mean. We know this. [i]Isaac[/i] gave us that satisfaction as we [i]learn[/i] the system enough to eventually be able to overcome and win. Great.

[b]The problem is with the idea of difficulty.[/b] Contrary to what this game may try, you can't just keep ramping up the difficulty and expect to get a proportionally satisifying game. While experience will vary from player to player depending on skill, but eventually even the best get tired of repeating the same levels over and over [i]ad nauseum[/i].

Because I'm a huge Edmund fan, I'll definitely keep on grinding with [i]The End is Nigh[/i], but I doubt my recommendation will change. I also see the community lashing out at negative reviews with less than about 3 hours of playtime. The mechanics in this game don't change significantly over time. You have to look at things from the right scale. If you don't like frustratingly hard platforming, you certainly don't need to get 10 hours in to make a judgement call. Do you learn new nuances of the platforming mechanic over larger time? Absolutely. Does this ever change into something that is not a 'hard-as-nails' twitch platformer? Nope.

[b]Pros:[/b]
+Beautiful artwork.
+Music is nice. Ridiculon is hit or miss with me. I often wish Edmund could go back to Danny, but that isn't going to happen. This soundtrack is quite refreshing for this band, which is great.
+Controls are super tight (what else would you expect!).
+Tons of hours of quality gaming if you like super hard platformers.

[b]Cons:[/b]
-Not innovative for Edmund. We love you bro, but you already changed the platforming world. Go rebuild another genre!
-The color palettes are really neat, but too bland. Needs more color contrast to make things 'pop'.
-Too difficult for my tastes. Again, as I discussed above, difficulty can be a vehicle for satisfaction - but there is an endpoint. Diminishing returns and all that.

[b]This is a love letter to Edmund encouraging him to make riskier stuff.[/b] Your games change the world, but you gotta make new ones with new mechanics to push forward.

Peace,

[h1] The End is Nigh[/h1] 

The End Is Nigh emerge un mundo totalmente perfecto con más de 600 habitaciones con sus propios coleccionables, enemigos que poseen rasgos únicos y secretos, una infinidad de secretos. Llegar al 100% es una tarea absurdamente complicada. Por suerte, el juego goza de un control preciso, pero lamentablemente caer en los sitios correctos u alcanzar una saliente costara 10-20- e incluso 50 o 60 intentos. Es un juego para morir constantemente y de ese modo encontrar el patrón y el timing perfecto para cada acción. 

The End is Nigh es mucho más que un plataformas, también funciona como un asombroso simulador de estrés y frustración, pero eso sí, es adictivo como él solo. Un Must-Have para todo fanático de SMB y los buenos plataformas. Como de costumbre, Edmund no defrauda y trae otra humilde y gloriosa obra de arte.

Сама игра- это весьма хардкорный платформер, который явно заставит Вас попотеть. Сразу хочу отметить, что она не копирует Super Meat Boy, с которым все её сравнивают. 
Геймплей в The End Is Nigh мне показался даже более дружелюбным к игроку, чем геймплей Super Meat Boy (Ни в коем разе не принижаю Мясного Пацана). 
Поэтому, если Вы хотите попробовать себя в этом жанре, то, при выборе между двумя играми от Эдмунда МакМиллена, я советую сначала сыграть в The End Is Nigh. Если Вам понравится, то ознакомьтесь и с Super Meat Boy.

Стилистически мне всё очень понравилось. Весь этот постапокалипсис, главный герой- Эш и прочие элементы обладают своим собственным шармом.

Музыка мне тоже пришлась по душе. Эти необычные переработки классики звучат замечательно и значительно влияют на атмосферу. (Хотя музыка- это скорее дело вкуса. Тут всё субъективно)

Ещё я хочу отметить секреты, отсылки и необычный юмор The End Is Nigh. Эти элементы не перестают радовать на протяжении прохождения. 

Итак, игра мне очень понравилась. Все её элементы выполнены хорошо. Если вас не страшит сложность, то настоятельно рекомендую ознакомиться с The End Is Nigh!

33555587.review:
The End is Nigh a very great spiritual successor to Edmund McMillen and Team Meat's addicting Super Meat Boy. 
Edmund McMillen and Tyler Glaiel's new beast of a game is one of my new favorites.

The objective of the game is to make a friend, and you do that by going through levels to find pieces of this friend. The story behind it, is gloriously macabre because the character you play as has nothing better to do since the apocalypse. You'll get a kick out of the cutscenes that play when you progress through the game because Ash is voiced by Rich Evans from Red Letter Media. The music is stellar thanks to Ridiculon, so no point in the game ever feels dull. The music matches the graphics, a grim world with our character going through a wide variety of settings and themes. All of the aesthetics of the game gets packed into this charming 2D HELL of a precision platformer.

The layout of the game is a open-world 2D platformer. The worlds interconnect, so there are many routes to take, nearly a hundred secrets and there's multiple endings. The game just won't stop coming at you just when you think you are done!

The worlds will challenge you, and you will die. The secrets in the worlds will challenge you further, and you will die more. The cartridges that can be found as secret collectibles you can play at home will definitely challenge you to your limit, you will never not die. 100%ing the entire game and getting all achievements is nearly impossible, but aiming to 100% a save file is doable. There's something that will get to you. One cartridge kept me from 100% for 6 hours. Doing that deathless is about double that practice.

The controls are smooth and tight at the same time. The mechanics can be quickly understood, but the true meat of the game lies with how advanced the movement can get. The option for speeding through the game dying as little as possible is on the table.

I can't get enough of this game, if 2D platformers appeal to you at all, this is a must. You might have a great time looking for tumors, or have a mind-boggling time seeing how deep this game goes.

33554284.review:
TLDR; I absolutely love this gosh dang game

This game is just super amazing. Every single piece of it is polished to a tee.

The controls are tight and responsive. You are always in complete control and any mistake is your own. The jumps are smooth and the game quickly helps you understand how every jump feels. Even more responsive than Meat Boy, imo.

The visuals are fantastic. The platforms stand out well from the background, always making it clear where you have to go. The lines are smooth and the background design is lovely

THE MUSIC. I found Ridiculon's stuff in Isaac to be great, but nothing you would listen to out of the game. These tracks are straight up slamming and are definetely going onto my playlists.

The tumours and cartridges around the levels are a heap of fun to collect. They may takes hundreds of deaths sometimes. But that's OK, because the resets are quick and fluid, making sure you are right back into the action.

Unlike Edmund's previous platformer, this game has a more fluid level progress, allowing you to just breeze through all the gameplay, with no menuing to break up the action. The map design of this game also allows for little secret areas, which allow you to get more cartridges and tumours

If I had to have a gripe with this game, it would have to be how much info it gives on the controls. There are things that I had to discover myself that would have helped a lot more if I had found them 10 minutes earlier into the current screen.

Edmund has really outdone himself, making a Super Meat Boy for the (even more) modern gaming age. 10/10

Imagine Super Meat Boy.  Now remove the wall jumps.  Now remove the world map and make it so that moving off the screen edge put you into the next room.  Oh, and add a bandage to every room.  Same excellent precision platforming, same tight controls, same instant-respawning-after-death pace, same exponential difficulty curve.

The level design is the biggest departure from Super Meat Boy, and it works quite well, with lots of secrets to discover and many clever ways it interacts with how you move about the map.

33548349.review:
Jeu tout simplement génial ! On retrouve beaucoup de points en communs avec Super Meat Boy mais cependant le jeu a l'air plus accessible.

Les différents mondes rencontrés offrent des éléments de gameplay innovants (phases sou l'eau, échapper au gaz mortel, rebondir sur des ennemis, casser des murs, etc...) et surtout la patte artistique apportés aux différents tableaux est juste magnifique : niveaux sombres, aquatiques, dans la lave ou encore dans le ciel, on a l'impression de toucher un nouveau jeu à chaque changement de monde et ce pour notre plus grand plaisir (car si vous voulez obtenir tous les collectibles vous allez recommencer beauuuuuucoup de fois certains niveaux).

La plupart des tableaux nous offrent la possibilité de ramasser une tumeur : principal collectible de ce jeu. On notera la présence de maxi-tumeurs (qui représentent 5 tumeurs) la plupart du temps dans des zones bien cachées ou difficiles d'accès.
Visiter certaines zones secrètes ou encore récolter ces tumeurs permettra d'ouvrir de nouvelles zones pour récupérer des cassettes dévérouillant des sortes de niveaux old-school un peu à la façon des warp-zones sur Super Meat Boy.
Ces niveaux sont généralement assez techniques et proposeront différents défis afin de dévérouiller des succès steam.

Pour conclure je mettrai 9/10 à ce bijou dont le seul reproche que je pourrais faire est le scénario : on est lâchés au beau milieu du jeu sans vraiment comprendre  pourquoi ou encore notre objectif, même si Edmund Mcmillen nous a habitué à des histoires interprétables, je trouve celle-ci légèrement plus vague que celle des jeux précédents (notamment Isaac avec toutes ses fins). Le jeu n'en reste pas moi un chef-d'oeuvre pour les fans de jeu de plateformes !

After spending about 45 minutes on The End Is Nigh, I'm forced to ask why McMillen decided it would be a good idea to remake one of his most popular games ages later, but slow it down, make it dull and bland looking, and sell it for 15$. Level design is punishing in a unfair way, such that many levels are impossible to complete on the first try simply because there are little to no clues about what is going to happen (which parts of the level will move, what is passable/unpassable terrain, etc). Trial and error was in meatboy too, but usually because of timing errors or figuring out a new obstacle. Here it is because there is no way to tell what kind of obstacles you are facing before it is too late.

Before finishing the first world I was too bored to care about collecting all the tumors, and the game is a failure if only for that: I stopped caring before I even really got into it.

I was looking forward to this game for weeks, and now I probably won't pick it up again.

Do yourself a favor and just replay Meatboy. It's a better game and you already own it.

33533715.review:
It is 4am. I am lying in bed and every time I shut my eyes, I wince at the image of dark shadows crushing my character over and over. I have been traumatized. My nerve injury in my shoulder is re-awakened after hours of non-stop split-second controller jerking. "Split-second" is an antiquated expression here. "Micro-second" is more appropriate.
There are levels that make you sun-blind which consist only of rich dark shades of red and black. There are levels that blur your vision intentionally. This is the first game that has given me vision issues after playing it, and I have played hundreds of games.
I love Ed McMillen's art, message, and the extremely tight controls of the his games. I only fear I've gotten too old to meet him with my reflexes. I will not be playing this more than once, unlike super meatboy/isaac. It is just too stressful.

33531459.review:
Fair warning: this is more of an Edmund McMillen game than a Tyler Glaiel one. It's also not a Metroidvania, even if it sometimes seems like it wants to be one.

At its core, The End Is Nigh is a twitch platformer in the vein of Super Meat Boy. In most levels, it's not too hard to figure out what you need to do in order to survive. The challenge is pressing and releasing the right controls with a split-second margin of error. Since I have the reflexes of a dying walrus, I was disappointed this isn't more of a puzzle platformer like Closure, but I appreciate that it doesn't try to trick you--if you can scout out a logical path through the level and are dextrous enough to execute it, you generally won't find yourself trapped or die in unfair ways.

Additional collectibles and story information can be found by searching out secret routes to hidden areas. This is where more puzzle aspects come into play, with some clever hiding places that rely on a precise understanding of the game's mechanics. However, this isn't really an "open-world" game, and most side paths will eventually return you to the linear progression of main levels. The limited amount of warp points also makes it something of a chore to go back for collectibles you missed the first time through the level.

At my current point in the game, I can't evaluate the story, but I find it striking that almost all of it so far is in hidden areas. Players who explore will get a very different impression of what's going on than players who stick to the main path. It reminds me of An Untitled Story, a Metroidvania with a similarly obscure approach to its world and characters.

I'm tempted to say that The End Is Nigh isn't really my thing, but the fact that I'm still playing it means it's at least a good game. If you like twitch platformers, you'll enjoy this game quite a bit.

33530171.review:
uper meat boy. Rien qu'à l'évoquation de ce jeu, l'excitation me parcours jusqu'à des parties pas nommables. Il s'agit du premier et seul jeu que j'ai eu la foi de speedrunner. Et pourtant, c'était pas gagné, j'ai mis énormement de temps à le finir la première fois, bloqué sur Omega, un des niveaux le plus dégueu du jeu. Prés de 6 ans aprés, Edmund McMillen revient pour un nouveau plateformer, cette fois ci sans son compère Tommy Refenes, mais épaulé par un Tyler Glaiel également talentueux.

Lorsqu'on commence à jouer à The end is nigh, une première chose saute à la tronche : c'est bien du McMillen. Niveau ambiance on est à la croisé d'un Isaac et Meat boy. C'est glauque, et toujours aussi débile. C'est jolie, sans folie. Le plus important : c'est clair, et facilement lisible. Et cette lisibilité, on va en avoir besoin, parceque tout comme son ancêtre, le nouveau McMillen est un plateformer exigeant et dur. Des morts il va en arriver, et pas qu'un peu. Les tableaux sont plus court qu'un Super meat boy. Ici, quelques sauts suffisent pour en venir à bout. Ash, le personnage étrange que vous dirigez n'est pas l'égal de meat boy. Il est plus lourd à diriger, prend plus de places et ne peut pas sauter de mur en mur comme le faisait son grand frère viandeu. Sa principale capacité est de s'accroché à des rebords ou à des crochets, ce qui vous obligera à bien évaluer les distances et à être précis dans vos sauts. Selon les mondes, les obstacles, et énnemies varieront et feront evoluer le gameplay. Par exemple, la possibilité d'aller sous l'eau et de plonger ou de remonter à toute vitesse. Ou encore la présence de nuages toxiques vous tuant en quelques secondes, vous obligeant à chercher des poches d'air tout en esquivant des pièges tordus. Des trouvailles comme ça, il y en a plein, et même si je suis bien avancé dans le jeu, je sais que je n'en ai pas encore fait le tour.

Parlons un peu de la difficulté du jeu. Elle est comme d'habitude, assez élevé, tout en vous offrant des choix. En effet, vous pouvez aller du début à la fin d'un niveau en ligne droite en prenant le moins de risque possible, ou bien vous pouvez au passage collecter les "tumeurs", objets vous permettant d'avoir accés à des niveaux secrets et de plus de vies dans les niveaux les plus dur du jeu. A vous de choisir, si vous voulez traverser le jeu le plus rapidement possible, ou d'en faire le tour complet, vous facilitant au passage la fin du jeu. Il y aura toujours une récompense  équivalente à votre prise de risque. Et c'est ce dosage si particulier de la difficulté qui fait de The end is nigh un jeu plaisant à parcourir. Certes, c'est dur. Certes, la frustration sera présente. Mais vos reussites seront gratiffiantes, débloquant des niveaux secrets typés retro ou des niveaux hardcore.

Concernant la partie musicale, passer aprés Danny Baranowski parait compliqué. Et le choix de remixer de la musique classique est vraiment particulier. Je trouve personnellement que ça ne colle pas nécessairement bien avec l'esprit du jeu dans la plupart des niveaux. Et le souci de connaitre ces musiques est ce sentiment de lassitude face à ces airs qui tournent trés vite en boucle et restent en tête. Il s'agit pour moi de la partie la moins réussi du jeu, mais je vous rassure, on est loin d'une plantade : ça reste dans l'ensemble agréable à l'oreille.

Que dire de plus, si ce n'est que le contenu en levels est conséquent et qu'en faire le tour vous prendra un certain temps. Comptez une vingtaine de niveaux par monde multiplié par les 10 que j'ai pour l'instant découvert (et ce n'est pas fini), et je ne parle pas des niveaux du "future" et des niveaux rétro.

Alors, c'est mieux ou moins bien que Super meat boy ? Eh bien, c'est différent. Le gameplay est quand même assez différent. Mais sachez que ce The end is nigh est excellent et vous fera passé un été des plus salés.

NOTE : 8/10

+
De la plateforme difficile mais pas injuste
Une direction artistique toujours aussi soigné
Un contenu conséquent
 
-
La musique pas toujours en adéquation avec l'ambiance

33528925.review:
Original/ TLDR:

Welcome to Super I Wanna Be the Meat Bros <3

Yes, to me it seems like a nice mix of Super Meat Boy, I Wanna Be the Guy, and Super Mario bros 3. It is tough as nails, as well as very rewarding when you finally nail down a room that seemed impossible the first dozen deaths!

I'm three hours in and already have over fifteen hundred deaths...

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Updated: After playing more I will say this game is an 8.5 out of 10 for me so far. It continues to add new elements, and challange the player throughout the chapters progressions. It really reminds me of Super Meat Boy in that design.

The gameplay consists of a wide variety of platforming puzzle rooms, tight controls, and the classic humor you know and love from Edmund. Also a few deaths. Can't forget about those...

Going back to try and find secrets, and more tumors, is in the end fun. That adds a great deal of replayability. The NES era nostalgia that many design elements brings up is heavy and very much welcome. Even the complaint that you have to restart a world from the beginning each time seems to be apart of the triubute to old school gaming that this is. Back then you didn't save your game. If you wanted to play SMB3 you started from the beginning each time.

It isn't perfect though. There are some bugs that are being worked on, although non that will jump out as an evening ruiner. The puzzles at times can feel too obtuse, but again, that just reminds me of old school games where some secrets were rarely found without searching for them.

The biggest complaint to be had with the game is the backtracking. Some rooms can only be 100% done if you make sure to try again from the other direction. Which ones? You won't know... A few times I thought a tumor had to be backtracked, only to find out that the room closes off when you go through it. That means the easy mistake to try a backtrack attempt means that I HAVE to try again later from the beginning of that map/floor.

Not a crazy burden though with the ability to warp to any map/floor from the start menu.
-----------------------------------------------------------------

33528283.review:
This game is another Edmund McMillen masterpiece. With his characteristic design tones and themes.

I consider this an unofficial super meat boy 2. The mechanics are similar, but instead of having a wall jump, you can cling to edges.

It's a hardcore precise platformer. Really hard. But really rewarding. [b]If you enjoyed SMB[/b], you are sure to enjoy The End Is Nigh.

That is all. I might expand on 100% completion, but with near 15 hours played, it's a recommended game for sure. One I've been waiting for a while.


[b]EDIT[/b] Things to consider.

Going for 100% completion feels a bit grindy and a little frustrating at times. In contrast to supermeatboy, where you could choose the particular level you wanted to play, in TEIN you just pick the world and have to go through every level if you wanted to get to level 12, for example. 

Some worlds allow you to go through the levels backwards, while some don't, and that's where it gets frustrating. If you didn't get everything on the first or second go, you might have to re-play really hard levels to get that last thing you missed. 

This isn't that bad, I mean, it's a hard platformer, but it feels like these are just bad design choices that could've been avoided.

This is a surprisingly solid game so far. My biggest gripe is the music. A large number of tracks in The End is Nigh are remixes of songs in the public domain -- meaning you've definitely heard them before. The tracks are also EXTREMELY short, looping over and over again, which can become very agitating. I can see how some people may like the way they did music, but personally I don't at all.

Other than the issue I have with music, from a speedrunning perspective it seems like it's going to be fun. There's very precise movement in some places, which I was I fan of in Meat Boy. I've seen people wanting to augment their speed in some way, but when I play Meat Boy I basically never let go of the run button anyway.

If you're thinking of getting this game and you haven't played Super Meat Boy, go play that instead.
If you like Super Meat Boy and want more of the same type of game, this is an amazing game to turn to.

33525803.review:
Quick review

-Moderate/fast paced precision platforming
-Precise Jumps
-Precise air control
-Good ground movement speed
-Unique ledge grab mechanic - easy to learn, tough to master 
-100s of levels! Very content packed
-Donkey Kong Country like collectables and secrets
-Many hazards - stationary and in motion
-Many monsters - varied AI 
-Macabre art style - signature Edmund
-Beautifully programmed - Tyler
-Humourous
-Atmospheric, remade public domain classical music 
-Forgiving hitboxes
-High production
-Appropriate minimalist macabre story
-Difficult and rewarding - enough content for novices and more for experienced players
-Value for money 
-The most fun you can have when you're dead
-The End is Nigh

Long review

I have a bias towards enjoying platformers, certainly more than most, so I'll aim to keep this review as objective as I can -judging it solely as a platformer rather than a new creation from Edmund and Tyler.

For a completely new player to the game, its a precision platformer, all the way through to its core. Think Super Meat Boy, n++, Fenix rage, Life of Pixel, Slime San. It's a difficult game, with trial and error. Extremely suitable for skilled players, speedrunners, average players WITH patience, and fans of 2d platformers. I struggle to objectively recommend this to Edmund fans if you do NOT like platformers. Although, mileage will vary. Edmund fans surely expect challenge, and seem to love being thrown into difficult and atmospheric worlds even in genres they do not typically enjoy. Just look at the number of SMB fans who hate other platformers. Amazing. 
 
Level design... 
is varied and challenging. Individual static screens that helps player focus on where they are per screen, no jerky motion of scrolling background. This I cannot emphasise enough as a really important feature - it keeps screen still and allows player to do the movement. N++ does this of course. Player moves screen to screen (by exiting one side) horizontally for the most part, but sometimes downwards and upwards (DKC style). Secret areas are numerous, hidden away sometimes by environments that are queued to destruct based on players actions. Aforementioned destruction of environment is a novel level design feature which resets if player leaves the current screen and returns. This adds a new puzzle element to tricky precision platforming. Without spoiling too much - there is water to swim through, spikes, lots of monsters - sometimes with projectiles to avoid, all with varying AI. Threats can be in motion or staionary. There are more surprises that should really be discovered alone. It's very novel overall and I'd say has more level design surprises in precision platforming than I've ever seen. But do not worry, it's not a convoluted experience, each idea is fully fleshed out over hundreds and hunderds of screens. I'd describe the hazards as tightly packed. Far less width for running wildly. Less horizontality than Meat boy, but still with ample wide leaps that need to be calculated.  

Control/mechanics -
move, jump, and the big new move - grabbing ledges. 
Movement on ground...
is graceful, predictable. Not jerky - I suspect Ash's ground acceleration builds for a few split seconds before full speed. However it's subtle, not as pronounced as Meat Boy's heavier start, where ground acceleration provided quite a sticky and slower start, appropriate for the skinless boy. Ash has a slower full speed. Perfect for the dense level hazards.  
Movement in air...
from jumping is great. Very precise. Can stop air accelaration just like that, fall where you need to. Falls faster than meat boy I think. In air control is tuned well. Jump height variable to jump input time. Also jump distance is larger on the horizontal plane following a ledge grab. This takes a bit of time to adjust but its exciting. NO wall sliding NOR wall jumping. Overall the jumping feel has less of an overall horizontal pull (than meatboy) with more weight in vertical gravity. As mentioned above, falling is faster. Jump height is pretty decent and you can easily learn the limits in the early levels.
Ledge grabbing... 
is new, I believe Edmund is very proud of this mechanic. Grab onto either upper wall corners, or little thorn like looking spikes anywhere up a vertical wall side. It feels finicky at first but once you learn why you need it, its really fun. You may also ledge grab upper corners that have hazardous spikes on the top, merely a pixel way. This is extremely tight an execution, but its badass. I like to think of ledge grabbing in the same vein as hanging in the air or wall sliding in Super Meat Boy - both give you neceassry time to breath and adjust to plans in navigating the levels. Once you master it you can hang out on walls and enjoy a split second to then jump again. Its a welcome addition and produces a fluent stop start rhythm that makes sense within tightly woven hazards.  

Hitboxes...
are really good for me personally. I tested the waters when i started my game and just walked up to monsters. There is slight and small overlap of pixels (thank goodness) between player and hazards and its makes for a more enjoyable experience. The levels require tight excution therefore a bit of freedom to brush into a hazard goes a long way. 

I love the game. I hope this review is helpful for some of you.

PS - As much as I tried to discuss platfoming objectively - Edmund and his previous work was mentioned. This is retrospectively fairgame for me - Super Meat Boy, particularly, set precision platformers to be judged by new standards. Thanks for reading.

33512269.review:
I have just completed the game and I can definitively say that this game is an epic spiritual successor to Super Meat Boy, from the innocous start to the awesome finale.  Everything you could want in a platformer is present.  The graphics are smooth and well drawn, the art style is a cool take on the well-treaded post-apocolyptic motif.  The animations are snappy and expressive amd lighting is used to create a cool atmosphere.   Musically the game is a winner too, with remixes on classical tunes.  Some hit more than others, but when they do nail it, they nail it.  Got to give a shout out to the chiptune music that plays during the cart levels, such a seamless transition you'd think it was done 30 years ago.  Funny voice acting, when it is utilized.  A well-written but ambigious lore is present, but you will have to work to access some of it.

The ironic thing about this game is that there are Nintendo references all over the place, but this game actually stands toe to toe with anything they have made in a 2-D plane(mainly referring to the DKC reboots).  I've seen nods to Super Metroid, Mario 3, Mario World and others.  If you enjoyed the game Catherine, you'll notice this game takes a couple of design and structural cues from that amazing game as well.

The mechanics and gameplay are just as exacting and devilish as before, this time using compact level screens to propel the game forward.  The worlds all have thier twist on the gameplay, and the way they are able to design challenges down to the pixel is still impressive after Meatboy, because no one else does platforming this precise and distilled.  There is a clear and distinct skill progression, so you will notice yourself breezing through worlds you thought were insurmontable a few hours earlier.  You also can choose the order to play certain areas, which is a nice touch.  The hidden goodies are actually more than just bashing the cracked wall, some of these secrets are actually, well secrets.  Shh, don't tell anyone.   And the mini-games are sweet, though I'm just starting to tackle them after beating the game.  I recommened doing the same, as the skill level you will gain will make them more bearable.  But the puns and old school CRT filter are just oozing with charm.  

The lack of bosses is a bold design choice in itself, it's good that they didn't shoehorn something in just to check of a box.  


Overall this is an amazing value, and easily a game of the year canidate.  15 hours to beat a platformer, then add a ton more to get the achievements....buy this game full price and don't look back.

33511936.review:

33510675.review:
The End Is Nigh - это Super Meat Boy моей мечты.

Без сравнений более ранней игрой Эдмунда вряд ли обойдёшься. Super Meat Boy - это генератор мата, в котором надо было находить пластыри и пробегать уровни, объединённые по тематике, преодолевая садомазохистские препятствия. Всё это доставляло мне жуткое удовольствие.

The End Is Nigh - это множество экранов, из которых составлена единая локация. По умолчанию нужно просто бежать вправо. Собрал фрагмент, добежал до следующего экрана - прогресс сохранён. Но благодаря объединению уровней в единое целое, многие загадки решаются возвращением назад. Например, прыгнув с верхатуры на предыдущий экран, ты долетаешь до места, куда не мог попасть до этого, поговорить там с сумасбродной какулей и таким образом исследовать связный интересный мир, как в метроидвании. И всё это с геймплеем, по ощущениям напоминающим Super Meat Boy.

Плюсы:
+ Отзывчивое управление
+ Рисовка Эдмунда Макмиллана и его же аутентичный, полный символизма сюжет
+ Рок-версии классических музыкальных произведений на фоне

Минусы:
- Нет русского языка (на уровнях встречаются полезные подсказки). Скорее всего, поправят патчем.

Очень приятный адреналиновый платформер для любителей бросить вызов самому себе.

Полностью доволен покупкой.

Extremely fun and difficult, The End is Nigh is an adventure platformer that many fans of Edmunds prior work of SMB will find generally good. The game takes after SMB as well as Gish and Time Fcuk.

The game handles pretty much like SMB with the exception of the dash button is now a drop button. As a result its very satisfying to just navigate through the world -- also the seemless respawn animation makes the game very easy to pick up and get right back into the grit of the level.

The stages are composed of levels, and should be treated more like a platforming puzzles as opposed to SMBs adrenaline pumped test of reactions. The game will spike quickly in difficulty in comparison to SMBs curve and you should get a feel of difficulty well within your 2 hour refund period.

The idea of the game is less getting from point A to point B, but exploring the world and discovering collectibles. If you want the fast paced platforming of SMB, you will not find it here.

I highly recommend this game if you are looking for tight platforming and get a sense of achievement replaying levels to perfect them -- getting the collectible.

The music score is worth noting as it is comprised of all, if not mostly classical music tracks remixed.

33505896.review:
Aujourd’hui, on va parler de The end is nigh, le nouveau jeu de Edmund MC MILLEn, vous savez le mec qui a inventé le Super Meat Boy on Binding of Isaac, des jeux super Hardcore sur lequel les vrais Khey se comparent encore. Les concours de bites, c’est fini depuis que Super Meat Boy et Isaac sont sortis.

Je ne fais pas partie du public des jeux de Mc Millen, à part Isaac et fingered, son gros coup, Meatboy, est une œuvre majeure du jeu vidéo total qui m’est totalement inaccessible, dont je ne comprend pas la profondeur, ni l’engouement.

Oui, c’est vrai, je dois bien dire que mon handicap est un grand frein, non, en fait, c’est un élément qui m’empêche quasi totalement d’y jouer, 

Donc, The End is night est un platformer hardcore qui reprend le principe de supermeat boy : watmille niveaux, des sauts demandant d’avoir le compas dans les 2 yeux, des réflexes de progamers coréens, et une abnégation digne d’un Yogi proche du nirvana.
Dommage, parce que l’ambiance du jeu, elle est génial, sombre, ironique, cynique , du McMillen tout craché, la musique est superbe et met bien dans l’ambiance. Il est probablement moins exigeant que Super Meat Boy puisque les glissades ne sont plus au centre du gameplay, au début du jeu, en tout cas, le personnage n’adhère pas au mur, il ne peut se pendre qu’a des crochets ou aux rebors. Le gameplay ne propose aucune surprise, si bien que, à mon avis, l’engouement pour ce jeu sera bien moins important.

Est-ce un mauvais jeu parce que j’arrive à rien ? Absolument pas, le jeu propose une direction artistique superbement travaillée, , un plafond de maîtrise du gameplay suffisamment haut pour les gens qui sont intéressés par ce type de jeu mais je suis pas du tout le public visé. En fait si, parce que je pense que j'adorais ce genre de jeu mais clairement, je n'ai pas les capacités physiques pour aller très loin dans jeu.

Mais je reconnais que ce jeu est ce qu'il prétend être et c'est un excellent représentant du platformer hardcore mais pouvait-on en douter en sachant qui est au commande?

J'aimerais bien que MCMillen fasse un jeu moins exigeant car son univers artistique est passionnant et ce jeu en est le nouveau porte-drapeau, malheureusement, je ne peux pas en profiter, mais c'est ma faute, t'es un bon.

33503464.review:
Ein weiteres Spiel in dem McMillen mitgewirkt hat. Es kommt von der Qualität nahe an Super Meat Boy ran, ist meiner Meinung nach aber nicht ganz so gut wie SMB.

Ihr spielt einen Blob, der der letzte Überlebende ist. Seine letzte Videospiel-Kassette geht kaputt und nun macht er sich auf den Weg, Tumore und Körperteile zu sammeln um sich einen Freund zu bauen. Der Humor ist typisch McMillen, wie man ihn aus SMB und BOI kennt. Die mechaniken unterscheiden sich von Meat Boy. Ihr habt hier einige unterschiedliche Spielmechaniken die das Spiel als eigenständiges Spiel rechtfertigen. Zur Zeit dieser Review gibt es keine deutsche Sprachausgabe. Ich hatte allerdings keine Probleme die paar Sätze im Spiel mit meinem Schulenglisch zu verstehen.

Der Grafikstil ist typisch McMillen, allerdings oft etwas zu monoton für meinen Geschmack. Der Soundtrack ist gut. Nicht DannyB (Super Meat Boy, Binding of Isaac) gut aber gut. An der Steuerung konnte ich soweit nichts negatives feststellen. Präzise und zuverlässig.

Wie auch in SMB könnt Ihr Retro-Level finden. In dem Spiel sind das Videospiel-Kassetten die Ihr in Eurem Zuhause spielen könnt.

Wie man es von einem McMillen Spiel erwarten würde ist die Schwierigkeit recht hoch mit einer fähren Lernkurve. Die einzelnen Abschnitte sind wie bei SMB sehr kurz. Somit wird man nach dem Sterben nie zu weit zurück geworfen.

Meine ersten 30 Minuten mit dem Spiel könnt Ihr euch gerne in dem kommentierten Video anschauen.

33502369.review:
Although this game uses the same method of difficulty as Super Meat Boy by using rough controls, it still maintains a fun unique experience to say the least.  It also gives you a since of reward whenever you accomplish something, for example a difficult steam achievement or collecting a certain amount of tumors due to the immense difficulty that the player just went through.  Saying that, it's not the most difficult game I've ever played, escpcially not compared to Super Meat Boy, but I'm not saying that it's a walk in the park either.  
 
   The plot is pretty straightfoward, you're just a glob of black slime (quite remarkably similar to Gish), that has to survive a post-apocalyptic world where about everything including the enviroment and about every single other "dead" thing tries to kill you.  There's also some optionable collectables you can obtain and some video game cartridges similar to the warp zones of super meat boy.  

   In general, this game I would have to say is actually quite entertaining and exhilarating. The soundtrack isn't as good as compared to Edmund's other games, but it's not bad either.  I highly recommend for anyone reading this review to atleast play the game if you have a likeness playing high difficulty platformers and Edmund's previous games.

33501811.review:
Overall, this game feels much more balanced than Super Meat Boy.
The game is, at first, really accessible to newcomers and people who just want to enjoy a good platformer. The difficulty ramps up slowly, the progression is smoother than SMB for instance, which is a very nice thing.
Of course, since we are starting to get used to the developer, we know that things will eventually become really challenging (boy they do). I think it is safe to say that this game is indeed more difficult than Super Meat Boy, but sometimes to a point where it gets a bit ridiculous (like, ~10 screens to complete without dying or you have to start all over again).
But what makes this game so good is the fact that you really get a sense of exploration, since a LOT of the content is hidden through secret passages that will really challenge your sense of attention (and your skills).

No matter what type of gamer you are, I think it is safe to say that as long as you are not allergic to platformers, you will not be disapointed.
(Except with Retrograde's music, that thing was just plain annoying.)

33501549.review:
I was hyped for this game as soon as I heard about it. felt a little sceptical about the artstyle, which seemed just a tad less interesting than meatboy's style, but after spending a good night with the game, I can not recommend it enough! It's a true piece of art, hitting all the exact right notes. 

It is exactly enough like super meat boy, taking everything that made it great, but it's also exactly different enough to be a completely new game. It takes the addicting, quick style of respawning, the hard levels and the high tempo, but adds exploration and collecting to the mix. Adding a lot of original, new environmental dangers to the mix, this game is just an absolute joy to play.

Como fan desquiciado de Nicalis y el loco de los cojones de McMillen voy a dejar un análisis corto que deje un poco por sentado qué tal está el juego:

Si lo que esperáis es un Meat Boy, pues... Vais a tener un Meat boy. Este juego de plataformas se basa más en las susodichas plataformas que en un juego en el que tienes un tiempo límite para hacer algo o llegar a cierto sitio. Cierto es qué este juego es reminiscente de Super Meat Boy, pero a diferencia de ese juego aquí se intercambia el salto de pared por la capacidad de poder agarrarte a los bordes.

El control es perfecto, el movimiento es súper suave y todas y cada una de las muertes que tengáis van a sentirse completamente legítimas, por el momento no tuve ningún problema con el juego, y si en algún momento llegué a tener alguna queja en lo que llevo de partida a los pocos minutos se vió solucionada bajo mi comprensión de las mecánicas o la construcción de x nivel.

¿Os acordáis cuando por 2010/1011 se decía (Y de hecho se sigue diciendo, que rayos) que Meat Boy era un juego esencial en la biblioteca de Steam? Bien, este lo mejora todo. Probadlo, dadle un tiento y si no os mola para algo tenemos el servicio de devoluciones de Steam, yo desde luego pagué estos 15 euros bien a gusto.

33498231.review:
I love platformers. They're my favorite genre. Two and a half hours into The End is Nigh and I was just as much in love with it as I was with Super Meat Boy (which it most closely resembles, for obvious reasons). The controls are just as solid, the level design tight and the music utterly charming (so far, entirely classical music remixes. I grinned when I heard the Dvorak 9th symphony arrangement). And yes, it is HARD. I've died 628 times so far. The hidden areas in particular will test your skills (and patience).

If there's one major complaint I have, it's that the map system doesn't handle backtracking for collectables very well. It forces you to start at the beginning of the area whether you want to or not. This hasn't been a gigantic issue for the early areas but I imagine it'll get very frustrating in the harder later ones. Since there's a certain level of connectivity to the levels (although not as much as you might expect), I can understand why they went in this direction but I think the system could be tweaked a bit to cut down on needless padding. 

I know this game will keep me busy for hours to come. Lots and lots of content!

Не раздражает, что ли. Да, от возгорания никуда не денешься, но TEiN при этом не хочется выключать, удалять, удалять из коррзины, саму корзину тоже на всякий удалять. Нет, TEiN скорее бросает игроку вызов, нежели берет на слабо. TEiN, мне кажется, элегантный, красиво оформленный, дружелюбный Боши.

Стилистика. Ну есть у Эша и пустошей постапокалипсиса свой шарм. Митбой - персонаж сказки о любви и одиночестве, Эш задуман таким же нелепым, одиноким и задротистым, как и все мы. Ему действительно сопереживаешь.

33497906.review:
So far this game has been amazing. I've read the negative comments about the game, and I'm here to tell you why they're wrong. The first point that I want to stress is that NONE of them have even played for two hours. Why are you gonna write a review before even playing most of the game. The first thing pointed out was that they hated precision platforming and that the speed was slow. This is a different seeries to meat boy. They are trying out new things and ideas with every new "character series" that they bring in. They have a different core mechanic in each game that they make. This one so happens to be precision platforming which is one of the things that I love most. (not every platformer they make has to be meat boy). They also don't like the collectibles, while I enjoy them a lot. I like the cartridges a ton because they are just really hard versions of the game. I also like the idea of the tumors being collectibles that you can get at any time, but you just need to know how to get them. I like how they are used in the game. Meat boy had characters, The End is Nigh has harder and cooler levels from the collectibles. The next thing is the color scheme. They say it's bland. I mean if you knew what the game was about you can see why they used the colors they used. It even tells you in the title THE END IS NIGH. For those of you that don't get it, it's a post-apocalyptic world, so the colors are meant to be in a darker mood. I think the colors compliment the game well. The next thing is move restriction and the "speed" of the game. For those that didn't play meat boy, there were mechanics that were in the game, such as wall clinging/sliding/jumping and the "run button". For those of you that did play meat boy, I want you to think to yourself if you ever really found yourself in a position where you weren't holding that "run button" and then tell me that it was completely useless because there was no reason walk. They made is so that you didn't have to constantly hold a button to go at the speed that was meant for the game. I think the character's speed is great for precision platforming. I like this new mechanic of hanging off of certain walls. I felt like the wall clinging in meat boy was a bit wonky, and I enjoy being able to completely control what I hang on to. The next point is that the game is "if you're blind, screw you" which I sort of agree with. There's obviously some stuff that you won't see coming and that you'll have to deal with on your next life. But, get this, you have UNLIMITED lives. They want you to die. Hell, they even have a death counter on your profile screen. They expect you to die thousands of times. Even saying all this, it is definitely possible to beat this deathless from a blind playthrough. It isn't likely, but the shit they throw at you doesn't come 80 mph. It's reactable. Frame drops are another thing people complain about even though there are settings to turn the shaders down. >:( The final thing I want to talk about is the complaint about no variety. Play for more than one world, and you'll encounter different things. I don't know what else to say. Some of the enemies in the game are amazing. My favorite is probably the better versions of the Oobs. When I first saw them, I thought of how amazing it was to see them correcting the mistakes they did in meat boy. The Oobs were probably one of my least favorite enemies in the game because of they're rapid and, somewhat, unpredictable movement. I'm happy to see that they are looking back at their designs and reworking them. It really gives me hope for their future games. Now you may ask, "Why did you take time out of your day to write this? You dumbass." 1. I don't think the complaints for the game were warranted at all. 2. I have no life to waste. 3. I don't want people to turn their heads from this game because they read all of these bad things about the game and that it wasn't a "continuation of meat boy." 4. I think this game deserves better than what it's getting. It truly is an amazing game that I can see myself playing for 100+ hours.

In all, if you enjoy a challenge (and I mean a REALLY hard challenge) then I advise you to definitely put this at the top of your list of games to play. Even though I like this game, I acknowledge that people don't like games that are difficult and don't have the time/effort to put in to play this game. While it's hard for me to say this, I advise you to stay away from this game unless you, all of a sudden, have changed your mind about it.

33494894.review:
Huh. I actually don't like it. I've 100%-ed each game by Edmund so I've been a fan for a minute, but End is Nigh came out so quickly that I didn't have any expectations for it. The focus is far more on precision platforming. Meat Boy's charm was it's fluidity, speed, and precision platforming at 100 miles a minute. This is far more methodical and drawn out- not to mention a lot of forced trial and error. Collectables are pretty meh, with cartridges being a big ticket item. However, they're merely more stages in lo-fi graphics. Music is great. There's an odd charm to the fact that 30-50% of the soundrack is public domain music, but remixed with the gothic/rock stylings of Isaac. Animations and graphics are fantastic. Controls are perfect. It's a very self contained game- no map for each stage, no real cutscenes (so yes, you must backtrack through each world in its entirety to search for collectables. Your mileage may very on that one). But with no real charm, a bland color scheme for each world, little variety, and mostly just waiting, jumping in the right spot, and repeat (as opposed to Meat Boy's dynamic levels with far more obstacles and variety from different mechanics and speed that kept things fresh), 

End is Nigh is basically Meat Boy distilled down to its main mechanics, remove wall jumping and sprint, and in doing so switch the focus from fluidity to precision platforming over dull stages that never feel like they change and collectables that feel very empty and unrewarding

33493664.review:
The End Is Nigh is a competent platformer, and a worthy spiritual successor to Super Meat Boy.

Pros:
+The music is incredible. Its some of the best music I've heard in a game in a long time. It's all remixed classical music. Any fan of the genre will smile every time they hear the themes they're so used to hearing come from an orchestra instead come from an assortment of instruments that give the music new life.
+Controls are tight. Most of the time when you die you know it's your fault for missing a button push or being a little slow (I'll touch more on the other part of the time in a minute).
+The art is pretty. It's nothing mind blowingly pretty or anything, but if you've played any of the designers other games like The Binding of Isaac or Super Meat Boy then you know what to expect; high quality illustrations that make the envirornment of the game more enjoyable. 
+It's difficult. Every bit of progress you make is hard earned and it's very satisfying to reach a goal you've been working toward after suffering death after death. There's even added difficuly for completionists looking for the challenge in the form of collectibles called tumors that are placed in hard to reach locations.
+The atmosphere is well constructed. The game is funny, but it delves into extremely dark subject matter such as death, an apocalypse, and even subtle notes of necrophelia. The art and music both help to promote this eeriness while not taking itself too seriously by using dark muted colors (primarily grays) and primarily upbeat music that can make you laugh at a death and keep everything lighthearted when you reach your 100th death on a single screen.
+The story is compelling. The "npcs" you meet hint at a future betrayal and some deeper meaning to the death of everyone around you. That's all I can say about it without spoiling anything.
+The game runs well. Programmed by Tyler Glaiel, the program makes excellent use of his own engine, and is able to run on haardware that isn't necessarily suited to gaming while still looking great and maintaining a high frame rate.


Cons:
-It's difficult. I list this twice because there are moments when the challenge can become too much, and you can feel like you're dying for things that aren't really your fault. There is an enemy in the 4th or 5th area (depending on your choice of progression) that moves without much pattern and there's not a whole lot you can do to influence it in a specific direction except for continue to die and restart the level. On several occasions it didn't feel like I was playing a challenging platformer but rather that I was rolling the dice only to come up with snake eyes every time. I have yet to be able to reach that collectible due to the sporadic nature of these foes.
-The music kind of loops a lot. The music is great, and because of my own love for classical music I didn't mind too much, but there were times when I thought to myself that if I hear Hungarian Dance No. 5 one more time I'm going to lose my mind. This is really the only piece I've felt this way with, but it doesn't change the fact that all the others loop a lot as well. 

As you can see by the absolute domination of pros compared to cons on the list; I've clearly enjoyed my time with The End Is Nigh. There is plenty of content and it's extremely enjoyable while providing a formiddable challenge to the completionist in me. I highly reccomend this game to anyone who liked the previous king of soul crushing platformers: Super Meat Boy, or really to anyone who enjoys platformers in general. It's exactly the kind of game I've been looking for, and will no doubt go down as a classic with the rest of Edmund McMillen's works.

33492315.review:
Basic movement system of Super Meat Boy minus the ability to wall cling/slide and wall jump.  That mechanic is replaced by a corner hanging mechanic which turns the gameplay into a series of tedious precision jump puzzles.  The movement is so restricted that it takes most of the fun out of the game.  You'd think the ability to wall jump would be a small thing, but it really makes the gameplay trudge to a stop without it.  

Since the rooms are so small and self-contained (failure means you respawn at the side of the room you entered), most of the challenge comes from things falling from the ceiling that looked like they were stable, or platforms moving that looked like they were stable.  It exchanges the relatively straightforward and fair difficulty of SMB for "screw you for playing this blind" difficulty, where the first few tries through a room are likely going to fail because of obstacles you couldn't see or account for.  This is compounded by the monochrome color pallete where spikes can sometimes be confusing to pick out from the background.

The addition of a loud, annoying voice for the main character adds nothing, thankfully it only seems to pop up in cutscenes and they're skippable on the first viewing.  Unfortunately, there's no way to turn them off completely.

In conclusion, don't buy this expecting a continuation of Super Meat Boy.  It's not that, and you'll likely be disappointed the same way I was if you go in with that mentality.

Эдмунд наконец-то выпустил новую игру! Да еще какую! Духовный наследник Super meat boy. Игры как минимум схожи плавностью картинки, приятной, но мрачной стилистикой, и очень удобным управлением. 
Как мы знаем в платформерах самая важная часть - управление. Оно просто замечательное, естественно рекомендую играть с джойстиком для полного наслаждения процессом игры. В сложных платформерах я ценю чувство продвижения. Именно продвижение дарит тебе силы попытаться пройти ненавистный и ужасно тяжелый уровень. В The Endi Is Nigh особенно чувствуется это продвижение. Каждая новая попытка приближает тебя к финишу, он все заметнее и заметнее. Пусть ты потратишь больше двухста жизней в одном месте, ты на этом не остановишься, ведь ты чувствуешь насколько лучше ты проходишь сложный этап по сравнению с первыми попытками. Думаю, именно это держит меня в игре до сих пор.
Сама игра представляет из себя набор экранов в разных мирах, переход с одного экрана на другой сохраняется. На каждом экране летает некая опухоль, которую желательно поймать, из опыта скажу, что без собирательства данных частей игра кажется гораздо проще, чем тот же мясной парень, но стоит поставить себе задачу поймать все опухоли - игра приобретает новые краски.
А саундтрек какой прекрасный, одно удовольствие было слушать микс на "Пляску смерти" Камиля Сен-Санса в первом мире.
[b]Рекомендую всем! Вот настоящая инди с душой![/b]

33487624.review:
Updating this review now that I've played through a lot more of the game, now that I'm at 75% completion, now that I got most of the collectibles (including secrets), and now that I made a "friend" (which is the objective given to you at beginning of the game, so no real spoilers there). Unless you're some sort of platforming deity, two hours is not enough to get a good feel for the game.

Okay, first off, this is a hard game, especially if you're going to be going for collectibles. The levels get quite unforgiving quite quickly, even in the first area, and the difference in timing between success and failure can sometimes be measured in tenths of seconds. Additionally, the controls are really precise, so when you screw up, you don't have anyone to blame except yourself. Therefore, it's not for everyone.

Second... I like this game. It has its charm, and it has the sort of charm that you'd expect a lovechild of Edmund M (Time Fcuk, Super Meat Boy, et al.) and Tyler Glaiel (Closure) to have. Invariably, there are going to be comparisons to Super Meat Boy, but this doesn't do either game justice. TEIN is a slower, more precise, and more methodical experience with bursts of intensity throughout. There isn't a timer that you're racing to get A+, there are no alternate characters that are better-suited to certain levels than others, and the obstacles that TEIN offers are different than those in SMB, but not inherently simpler. TEIN's levels are dynamic in a different way than SMB's as entire sections of the map can move and react to the player in a way that didn't happen in SMB. Additionally, TEIN has to be the one modern platformer that doesn't have homing missiles anywhere in the main game. If you're expecting another SMB, this is not it. This is barely even a spiritual successor, and that's okay.

Death is a frequently occuring event but one you recover from quickly. Ash controls very well in the air and doesn't keep his momentum upon releasing a movement key (which may or may not be your thing, but does make landings onto small platforms easier). The individual levels are for the most part short and focus on one idea at a time (though there are plenty of exceptions to both). The areas each have their own distinct styles and mechanics.

The game's tumors are a nice mechanic. They're collectibles that you have to enter a level, collect, and then leave the level by some means other than warping using the map to keep, and they're present in practically every level. For the most part they are gained by taking a harder route through an area, backtracking, or getting in and out of a hidden area (which gives you five at a time). If you lack the skill or patience to get one, you can always skip it any come back to it later. They're optional, although they unlock additional levels for you and become very important in late game (specifically, [spoiler]they act as revives later on, which, considering you can get over four hundred of them, gives you an idea of how much the game expects you to die[/spoiler]).

The game also has its retro levels, and quite a lot of them. Some give you ten lives (nine revives) and a continue to get ten more, some require you to beat the level sequence without dying, and some have progression similar to the main game. Accessing them requires you to get game cartridges, which are usually tucked away in hidden levels and don't require you to leave the level to keep them. As an added incentive to do the retro levels, completing them gives you bonus tumors. The better you do, the more bonus tumors you get.

In terms of performance, the game runs really well at full resolution, even with all the settings turned to max on mid-range current-gen hardware. However, as it is a vector graphics game, lower-end computers may still stuffer while running it (even with Glaiel's tricks).

However, that's not to say the game is without its faults.

While there is a warp system, the warp points only take you to the start of each area and not all of the levels are traversible in the opposite direction, meaning if there's a collectible closer to the end than the beginning, you may have to traverse all the way from the beginning of an area to get it anyway. This leads to a lot of retracing your steps. At least it's practice, right?

It doesn't always feel like the game explores its own mechanics to their potential fullest. I would have preferred if the areas were each 5-10 levels longer to better explore the possibilities that interactions between the different obstacles and mechanics could provide.

The challenge/reward balance is sorely lacking at times. Some individual tumors are obscenely hard to get, while others the game practically gives away for free. The worst offenders are the "locked" levels, which contain some of the most difficult challenges in the game in exchange for a mega tumor, which is the same reward as most other secret areas. There's only one locked level that gives something different/maybe better, and it's markedly easier. Additionally, unlocking those challenges consumes your key and you usually have to go partway through the challenge to get another one, meaning if you accidentally bump into one of the locks with a key (which can happen as several of them have to be jumped over to avoid), in the worst case you'll be barred from progression through the main game (as there is an area that makes heavy use of keys and locks) until you get the key back. Fortunately, there is no way to permanently lock yourself out of the locked areas.

Some of the keyboard controls (none of which are directly gameplay related) are screwy. For instance, many interactions respond to the Up binding as well as Interact. Additionally, warping directly from a warp point allows you to use your Interact keybinding to confirm the warp, but warping from an arbitrary area in the game using the map requires you to use Space instead. Glaiel's twitter implies that the latter is a feature instead of a bug intended to reduce accidental warping, but there are plenty of games that require you to hold down the key to confirm a critical action, and the game is paused while the map is open, meaning I'm not buying this justification.

Finally, Ridiculon's soundtrack hit and miss for me, even with the classical adaptation theme. It's more miss than hit in the beginning (anyone else notice this pattern?), as some of the pieces feel like they're far too upbeat and loud for the game they're in. There is one particularly grevious offender around midgame which I know was supposed to fit with the hectic nature of the area, but actually succeeded in putting me off from the area entirely until I turned the music off (for those curious, it was [spoiler]Retrograde[/spoiler]). They also missed a glorious opportunity to have an adaptation of Liszt's Totentanz, which doesn't appear anywhere in the game or the OST.

All in all, however, another good hard platformer from Edmund & friends. I know I spent a lot of time writing about the negative points, but I do still seriously enjoy this game. Buy it if you're into hard platformers that require incredibly accurate movements.

33487565.review:
Будем честными - описывать эту игру с нуля нет смысла, то есть эти отзывы будут читать, и в игру будут играть те, кто или слышал о Митбое или играл в него и захочет узнать "тоже самое или по-другому, сложнее или проще".
Но так даже лучше. Потому что эта игра и сама ведёт диалог с Митбоем.
Митбой злил казуальных игроков. Эта игра злит игроков, проходивших Митбой.
Митбой был сложной игрой с плавной, но при этом длинной долгой кривой возрастающей сложности. Эта игра почти сходу, не считая обучающих экранов, начинает примерно с третьего мира Митбоя.
Митбой подстёгивал первые четыре мира лишь статистикой скорости, в целом давая возможность проходить отдельные участки, предварительно отдышавшись (кроме боссов, пожалуй, которые, не смотря на скорость, были скорее самой простой частью игры). Здесь же почти все экраны, начиная с первых, действуют по принципу "сделал два шага от начала - запустил цепную реакцию по эффекту домино, и теперь каждый шаг, прыжок и скольжение не терпят отлагательств". Достаточно сказать, что первый экран, требующий абсолютно идеального тайминга, здесь появляется на пятнадцатой минуте игры.
Митбой испытывал реакцию игрока в точке Х, разбрасывая эти точки по экрану, но эта игра выходит на новый уровень - здесь мы - кусок скользящего солидола, который из-за своей инерции пожинает плоды ошибок спустя несколько прыжков после того самого, который и таил в себе ошибку, став бомбой замедленного действия. Например, Вы можете прыгнуть и выжить, потом прыгнуть - и выжить, прыгнуть - выжить, и лишь на четвёртом прыжке умирать раз за разом, так и не осознав, что смерть на этом прыжке - это прямое следствие из неправильности именно ПЕРВОГО прыжка. Это похоже на симулятор человека, потерявшего равновесие - не так поставленная нога не обрушит вас здесь и сейчас, но именно здесь и сейчас решается ваша судьба - упадёте вы через пять секунд или восстановите равновесие.
Вообще, игра как будто знает, КАК проходили игроки Митбой, и нарочно любит "подрывать" темп митбойщины - расставляя моменты, где нужно подождать, аккурат посреди моментов, где ждать ну никак нельзя и надо бежать. Там, где нам кажется "тут нужен быстрый прыжок" игра на самом деле ждёт от нас серию из кучи маленьких, а там, где, как нам кажется, шипы так близко, что надо действовать осторожно и хирургически точно, на самом деле нужно... делать всё это одновременно быстро и хирургически точно, да.
Я уже предвижу, что толпы людей, демонстрируя витрину достижений Митбоя, буду гнобить эту игру за "поломанную, в отличии от митбоя, сложность", но это плохой подход к игре с их стороны. Эта игра - кривое зеркало Митбоя, требующее от нас не только понимание траекторий прыжков, но и понимания траектории скольжений и инерций, делающая неудобство в управлении частью механики (как surgeon simulator или manuel samuel).
Ну, а в остальном - фирменный почерк МакМилана тут чувствуется повсюду - ворчащие скелеты, говорящие, "исследование мира приносят страдания, вот я исследовал свой внутренний мир - и теперь лишь скелет", скучающие мёртвые киты, маленькие чёрные духи, которые своими глазами вечно следят за нами, чип-тюновый "танец троллей" на фоне, прохладные тона канализаций, отсылки к ретро-культуре и всё, за что мы и любим игры МакМилана со времён его первых техно-демок гиша.

33487540.review:
[h1]Super Meat Boy?[/h1]

Как бы нам не хотелось, снова поиграть в Super Meat Boy, но увы это пока не случилось. 

Может показаться, что игра не очень сложная. Да это так, если просто бежать с одной части экрана до другой. Но ситуация меняется в обратную сторону, как только мы захотим собрать своих собратьев, на каждом из уровней. 

К тому же в каждой главе присутствуют запрятанные уровни + игровые карты(это своего рода мини игры, в которых к примеру нужно собрать 100 колец). И все это сделать достаточно сложно... десятки, сотни или даже тысячи смертей. Как по мне настоящий челендж.

Что лично мне не нравится, так это то что в некоторых уровнях нужно зацепиться за уступ на котором шипы. Это жутко напрягает, 1 миллиметр левее или правее прыгнешь и сразу труп. Особенно эта боль ощущается в картриджах, если хотим их пройти на 100%.

Не нравится, что нельзя вернуться в предыдущий уровень. Только что была ситуация, что случайно прошел 15 уровень The Hollows, а "опухоль" не взял, а назад никак. Теперь все проходить снова с 1 уровня.

В целом не смотря вот на такие минусы, покупкой доволен.

Несколько уровней с геймплеем игры.
Иногда придется подумать:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=viWld11fjw4&list=PLm6579GLBap02pDnaG_d8V1KBDz7-9nuZ&index=8
